overview: Our school is part of a national network of excellent all-girls college prep schools. Our school is guided by teachers and staff who nurture students' intellectual curiosity and work to empower young women. We believe that all students can achieve high standards in every area including math, science, and technology. We have a very supportive environment that includes daily advisory. Part of a network of Young Women's Leadership Network (YWLN) schools, we are an all-girls school with a mission to prepare young women to be successful leaders in their communities. Every YWLN school is supported by the CollegeBound Initiative (CBI) which ensures college access and financial aid options for every student. We work with parents as partners in preparing every student for post-secondary opportunities.

overview: Our school is known for being academic, artistic, and athletic while providing a warm and welcoming community. Our teachers meet weekly to create rich, meaningful curricula. All students have a CORE teacher responsible for monitoring their progress. Our college- and career-readiness curriculum helps our students become competitive candidates for college and prepares them for the rigors of life after high school. Come to a place where people know you well and are dedicated to supporting your future goals. Many of our staff members have been here for more than 10 years and our graduates often come back and visit. Once you are part of the Wagner family, you will always be a part of the Wagner family!

overview: At I.S. 5, we talk like scholars, write like experts, think like innovators, and live like leaders. Students appreciate that I.S. 5 provides them with a nurturing learning environment which is focused on developing their academic, emotional, and social needs. They also enjoy the smaller learning environments our communities provide as they can readily communicate with administrators and/or teachers as it relates to their growth. I.S. 5 consists of four learning communities commonly referred to as Community of Scholars, Community of Leaders, Community of Innovators, and Community of Leaders. Our school community is currently engaging in opportunities for project-based learning, with hands-on projects that highlight the importance of global citizenship and the legacies of our contributions in the community at large. We are building student socio- emotional growth through the incorporation of Leader in Me, based on the work of Franklin Covey. Teachers utilize Mastery Connect and Skedula to track student progress, drive instruction, and communicate with parents on a daily basis.

P.S./I.S. 49 has won many awards for academic achievement. The school is committed to professional development and innovation.

overview: Students in our school are fully immersed in differentiated instruction that targets their individual learning needs. Students are able to select up to two talent activities each school year. I.S. 61 has created five academies within the main school that foster a nurturing environment for our students. Each academy is set up with its own dean, guidance counselor, assistant principal, and staff of teachers, therefore creating a small learning community. Parents are also able to track their child’s progress for each unit through a special Engrade account. To support our efforts to assist students in meeting the standards for college- and career-readiness, parents have an option to select our AGP program for their child. Students are expected to maintain an 85 GPA as well as take all Regents offered by the school. Programs are also available for parents of our school community, including English as a New Language (ENL), GED, and fitness programs.

overview: We are a diverse school community that is divided into five small learning communities called academies. Each of these academies serves as a smaller school within our building to help create and foster a nurturing environment for the students they house. We have done this by assigning each academy its own assistant principal, dean, guidance counselor, and staff of teachers. Each academy is geographically located in a specific area of the building and has its own lunch and assembly periods. In order to provide students with an opportunity to become active members of the school community, I.S. 73's Student Council has been established to enhance school spirit and to improve the overall student experience. These students are elected to one-year positions and serve as representatives of their grade level as well as their homeroom class. Student Council members are responsible for discussing school-wide concerns and activities during the year. In addition, our school provides all eighth graders the opportunity to take the Specialized High School Exam in school during the school day at I.S. 73. Kaplan provides free test prep prior to the exam for all of our students who choose to sit for the exam.

overview: Located on the 32-acre Frank Padavan Campus, P.S./I.S. 266 is a barrier-free building that offers a Common Core standards-based curriculum in all content areas. Students thrive in a nurturing setting where they build a strong personal connection that facilitates student achievement while meeting their emotional and social needs. The cornerstones of this atmosphere are rooted in developing: a community of learners where students, parents, and staff seek to expand their knowledge; building leadership capacity where all constituencies develop ownership of the school's mission, vision, and educational process; a collegial environment that emphasizes the learning process through sharing of knowledge, strategies, and methodologies; a school of philosophers where pertinent questions are asked ensuring vitality and growth. Our academic environment is one of great rigor, offering a range of honors courses in grades seven and eight, and a variety of special programs including Chess Club, CHAMPS, Real Heroes program, Youth Alive, Legion of Leaders, Debate Team, Tri-M, Drama Club Grades 6-8, Extravaganza Grades K-5, and Festival Choir Grades 5-8.

overview: I.S. 77 is a family of learners. We offer programs for special progress and honors, English as a New Language, and special education. We offer Spanish, with differentiation for native speakers. Each classroom is equipped with a laptop, a projector with a document camera, and speakers. There are opportunities for students to become involved in community outreach programs. We celebrate a Student of the Month based on virtues. We have a partnership with the Greater Ridgewood Youth Council who sponsors an after-school program which offers homework help, sports, and recreation in our school. We also work with the Youth Council in their young adult internship program which benefits many of our graduates. Our PTA is very active and encourages all parents to be a part of our family of learners. Through the use of the internet program PupilPath, parents and teachers are able to communicate with each other regarding grades and assignments.

Our curriculum and instruction in all major subject areas are aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards. Our Spanish Dual Language program and our STEM program are available to incoming students (includes LEGO Robotics, Coding, and our partnership with Urban Advantage, a premier NYC science organization). Additionally, we offer our students a wide variety of activities in the areas of sports, art, music, drama, and community service in partnership with the Greater Ridgewood Youth Council Beacon Program. overview: I.S. 125 is a well-developed school that provides instruction to a very diverse population of students from over 60 countries. Though a large school, we provide a safe, welcoming, and nurturing environment through our small learning communities. Students are divided into four houses with a dedicated assistant principal, guidance counselor, and dean. I.S. 125 offers an extensive arts program. Day and evening performances are offered throughout the school year. I.S. 125 has a unique accelerated program which provides the opportunity for gifted students to sit for Regents exams. Students graduate from I.S. 125 fully prepared for high school and, by extension, college and their career. Parents are an integral part of the I.S. 125 community. They are valued members of the School Leadership Team, PTA, and various other committees. We hold evening events, including a multicultural show and dinner. Weekly parent English as a New Language (ENL) and computer courses are offered.

Parents and families of our students appreciate our open communication and dialogue with our staff regarding the needs and next steps of their children. Because of our small size, parents and families are able to participate in many student activities, performances, and parent workshop sessions. Students in our school begin sixth grade with a focus on taking Regents courses and/or the Language Proficiency Exam upon completion of eighth grade. In addition, they participate in hands-on learning that takes them beyond the walls of the classroom.

overview: A dedicated staff and small school environment offer individualized social, emotional, and academic support. Queens Valley School offers all students high quality, differentiated instruction to prepare them for high school as well as college and/or a career. We value our technology program which includes SMART Boards, computers, and a state of the art lab. We offer an accelerated Regents program to all eligible eighth grade students. Our web-based programs include Castle Learning, Ed Performance, GoMath, Code X, Flocabulary, and MyOn Reading. Our Talent program provides students with an innovative and in-depth study in visual arts, dance, drama, vocal music, and video production. In addition, we have added a Talent track in coding and publishing; this provides our students with an opportunity to develop skills in STEM, computer programming, and graphic design. It is a vibrant program that strives to encourage and facilitate an enriched and creative environment. Our teachers model their artistic process with commitment to scaffold instruction. We have had students place as both finalists and semifinalists in the P.S. Art city-wide competition since its inception 10 years ago.

overview: We ensure our students are prepared for college and 21st Century careers. Our teachers provide support and enrichment in an inquiry-based environment. We incorporate STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Math) into the curriculum through our Collaborative Learning Program and Software Engineering Pilot. Students experience an interdisciplinary approach to learning through residency programs with Arts Connection, Silk Road Connect, and other cultural partners. Our students participate in engaging field trips, artist visits, and performances, and have won awards in science, math, robotics, art, spelling, and athletic competitions. We partner with Asia Society and Confucius Classrooms to provide our students with cultural experiences, and we offer Chinese language instruction and a dual language program. Parents are integral to our school community and they are invited to participate in activities and take on leadership roles. Daily communication between parents and our school is facilitated via our interactive website and Pupil Path online system.

overview: J.H.S. 189 provides opportunities for young people to be engaged in social action/community service projects. In this context, students identify problems as well as needs and seek solutions that make a difference. To that end, every person at J.H.S. 189 is involved in a year-long community service project. Giving back to the community is a core belief in our school’s culture. As a result, we have approximately 42 social action projects every year.

overview: J.H.S. 194 aims to educate children holistically by challenging all students academically, encouraging student voice, and supporting self-expression through a diverse fine and performing arts department, which includes: fine art, concert band, theater, film and media, dance, and photography. J.H.S. 194 strives to support students academically, socially, and emotionally through our grade-level academies, each with a dean, an assistant principal, and two shared guidance counselors. We house a Beacon program on-site which expands the choice of after-school activities for students. Our fine and performing arts department collaborates with numerous arts agencies throughout the city, including: New York City Center, Flushing Town Hall, Jazz from Lincoln Center, Magic Box, and the Leap Program. We have student council in every grade and encourage students to be active members in the planning of school events. We believe parental involvement is essential to student success. We welcome open communication with our families and host a variety of events throughout the year.

printedschoolname: The Magnet School of Global Studies & Leadership (P.S./M.S. 200)
overview: We are now The Magnet School of Global Studies & Leadership. Our students study nations and cultures from around the world and they explore ways in which they can become leaders and effect global change. In class, students have daily access to laptops and iPads to support their learning. Our curriculum emphasizes the use of STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) education to make the world a better place. We are a unique school because we are small, but we span grades PK-8. Middle school students engage in challenging lessons with each other each day, but they also act as mentors for younger students in the building. Our motto is: "200 Cares." We strive to build and maintain a caring school environment where all students feel welcome and supported. Middle school students engage in two semesters of enrichment electives each year, including topics like chess, media studies, yoga, comedic improvisation, journalism, community service, and sign language. In addition to the core academic subjects, we offer Spanish, Visual Arts, Drama, and Physical Education three times per week. We also invite middle school students to participate in sports and dance before school and to attend our free, daily after-school program.
name_prog1: The Magnet School of Global Studies & Leadership

overview: We are proud of our school. Teachers, students, and families are dedicated. We practice the concept of social justice which we translate to mean Equity Access, maximum inclusion for all. This is reflected in how we build our classes, organize all activities, and ensure that every student has access to all the school has to offer. Nearly all of our students take two Regents and our high passing rate reflects high expectations and high achievement for all students. The process starts for many of our students in pre-K and we welcome new students all along the way to eighth grade graduation! Parents appreciate how our school provides a challenging curriculum within a small learning community that promotes positive behavior. Our collaborative teams work together to set goals, to plan for effective instruction, and to monitor and assess student performance. The skills and strategies that students gain enable them to attain success and reach their potential. Our skilled staff supports families in many ways. Parents feel that the school creates a physically and emotionally secure environment in which everyone can focus on student learning. A quick visit to the school will reveal the family feel most visitors notice when they are here.

overview: I.S. 237 provides a robust and supportive middle school experience and, at the same time, promotes college and career readiness in multiple ways. Our strong academic program includes Special Progress (SP) courses on each grade level. Eighth grade SP students take Regents exams in Algebra, US History & Government, Earth Science, and Living Environment, as well as the Spanish Proficiency exam. Many students go on to attend Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, and Brooklyn Tech. English language learners receive instruction before, after, and during the school day as well as on Saturdays. All students receive instruction in visual arts, band, strings, or chorus. Our extended day programs include academic tutoring, basketball, musical theater, guitar, keyboard, and art. Our Debate and Math teams have won multiple district-, borough-, and city-wide tournaments. SONYC, a free after-school program, offers homework help and recreational activities Monday through Friday from 2:20pm-5pm, Monday and Wednesday evenings from 5pm-6:30pm, and is open during most school holidays. We welcome parent involvement at all times.

overview: I.S. 250 is a small learning environment which promotes lifelong learners who possess strong character, self-worth, and the tools needed to be productive citizens. Students will acquire the knowledge and skills to be college- and career-ready through a rigorous curriculum that addresses our diverse learners. All students are empowered to be confident, tolerant, and empathetic to their community while flourishing in a school that celebrates multi-culturalism, acceptance, and individuality. Our mission is to build a solid foundation focusing on social responsibility, hope for the future, and lifelong success—NO EXCEPTIONS!

The Queens School of Inquiry (QSI) is a neighborhood school that works with Queens College (QC) beginning in the sixth grade so that students may earn up to 60 free QC credits in high school. Parents appreciate the personal contact with their child's teachers and with the principal.

overview: We prepare students for college and career. We are a small, inclusive school supporting all students with two teachers in many core classes and a Nest program for students with autism, with one teacher per thirteen students allowing significant individual support. Students take math and ELA seven times a week and a language: Japanese (sixth grade), Korean (seventh grade), and Chinese (eighth grade). A robust environment embraces our four pillars: honor, excellence, curiosity, and celebration. We promote a positive, safe school atmosphere by encouraging acts of kindness through a nation-wide anti-bullying program: Rachel's Challenge. Friendships grow in our many clubs, advisory, and student government. Our parent coordinator keeps parents informed through bi-weekly postcards, a newsletter, and First Fridays. Assignments, grades, and attendance are available on Skedula. Our 6-12 model transitions students from middle school to high school and on to college. We are a Reward School with scores in the top 5% in all of New York State.

printedschoolname: World Journalism Preparatory: A College Board School
overview: Our students like the opportunities we present for self-directed learning and enjoy being active participants in our school culture. They also enjoy using technology across the curriculum. Parents value our project-based learning activities and our focus on journalism. They also appreciate that our seven-year curriculum carries students through a challenging, yet personalized, middle and high school program. Students run their own broadcast news show (The Highlight). Each student creates an online portfolio of his/her best academic work and they participate in student-led Portfolio Review Conferences. Everyone has a World Journalism Preparatory School (WJPS) email account. It is expected that students come to WJPS for a 7-year program (grades 6-12). Our middle school prepares students to succeed in our high school which is very academic and rigorous.

overview: BELL Academy is proudly recognized as a Schoolwide Enrichment Model. Following Dr. Renzulli's Schoolwide Enrichment Model allows us to place a strong focus on challenging our students in real world project-based learning, while taking their unique gifts and talents into consideration. With the support of talented and dedicated staff, all students are encouraged to develop their unique profile of talents. Students can experience up to three interactive Enrichment Clusters each year. Some of the Enrichment Clusters offered are Drama, Young Entrepreneurs, Projects for Peace, Future Community Leaders, Film, Healthy Living, and String Ensemble. Instructional technology is leveraged in meaningful ways to enhance student learning. All students have access to laptops, iPads, and SMART Board technology in every classroom. Our talented teachers engage our students in complex tasks and include components of STEAM learning to ensure students are best prepared for college, careers, and beyond. Students and families enjoy our small, nurturing environment, which allows parents and teachers to work collaboratively to provide optimum learning conditions for all students.

overview: Students at Dreyfus Intermediate School take pride in our strong focus in technology in our classrooms as well as our expanded Arts programs. Our seventh-grade students have the opportunity to participate in a year-long technology-based College and Career Readiness course that centers on career exploration, financial literacy, and computer applications. In eighth grade, students have the opportunity to participate in an elective course that teaches coding and game design. Dreyfus Intermediate is also a participant in the iZone where students take Spanish and Integrated Algebra in an online environment. The learning environment at Dreyfus gives students an opportunity to work with skilled, flexible, and committed teachers and administrators. Students also appreciate that they are able to communicate with the entire school community through the school's independent website Berta49.org. At Dreyfus Intermediate we believe that higher expectations lead to higher learning.

overview: Eagle Staten Island prepares all students to read, write, compute, speak well, and behave in socially acceptable ways. We are committed to meeting the needs of our students and providing them with the required support services to develop Confidence, Leadership, Effort, Academic Excellence, and Resilience (CLEAR); the core values of our school. Our scholars complete a challenging and interdisciplinary curriculum and are required to develop their critical-thinking, problem-solving, and questioning skills. Parents love our family-like atmosphere where staff members know them and each student personally. We believe that our young men are best developed in a structured environment, surrounded by dedicated educators, supportive parents, and actively engaged mentors.

overview: M.S. 358 is the latest pride and joy of Jamaica, Queens. Housed in a brand new, state-of-the-art building, students benefit from a safe and supportive learning environment. All students of M.S. 358 experience high-quality education that ensures that they are on the path towards college- and career-readiness. Students benefit from a staff that supports their academic achievement in addition to their social-emotional growth. Students have opportunities to explore STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Mathematics) through computer science courses. Providing students with the knowledge and skills of computer coding and computer programming is vital to being a 21st century citizen, which gives students a competitive edge in the evolving world of technology. In addition, M.S. 358 partners with non-profit organizations, colleges, and universities to prepare students and families for the transition to high school, college, and beyond. M.S. 358 also supports students to empower themselves through personal voice and ownership of their learning. Each year, students participate in student-led conferences (SLC) held one-to-two times per school year where they are able to share their academic and personal growth with their families.

overview: In addition to a rigorous academic curriculum aligned with Common Core Standards, Morris takes pride in its performing and visual arts programs. While there is a focus on the arts, Morris recognizes that student-centered engagement within a thinking curriculum provides each student with learning experiences that prepare them for college and beyond. Our literacy and math curricula provide the rigor to tackle the complexities of higher-order thinking texts and provide students opportunities for rich discourse. We have many community and cultural organizations as partners to enhance the learning experiences of our students. They include The Academy of Carnegie Hall, Juilliard School and Weill Music Institute, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Learning Through Expanded Arts Program, Art Lab, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, and Children's Aid Society. In order to provide students with an enriching educational experience that focuses on all facets of development, Morris also provides a STEAM program that promotes science, technology, engineering, the arts, and math as access points for guiding student inquiry, dialogue, and critical thinking. As an additional experience, Morris celebrates a championship girls and boys varsity basketball team.

Paulo is a strong supporter of the Staten Island Giving Circle, the Bread of Life Food Drive, Wounded Warriors, the Blythedale Children's Hospital Toy Drive and many other charities. Our performing arts department is recognized as outstanding throughout the community.

overview: The Michael J. Petrides School is committed to creating an environment for learning that nurtures the whole child—mind, body, and spirit. Teachers, parents, administrators, and support staff collaborate to provide an education that celebrates the diversity of our students and recognizes the individuality and creativity of each child. We engage students in active learning, developing self-esteem, and promoting literate, creative, lifelong learners. The Petrides School serves students in pre-kindergarten through grade twelve. Our unique organizational structure has allowed us to develop a truly seamless curriculum. Our stimulating learning environment offers an accelerated, rigorous curriculum, including rich arts opportunities for all students.

printedschoolname: The Staten Island School of Civic Leadership
overview: The Staten Island School of Civic Leadership recognizes that individuals in a society must be educated to be good citizens. We are focused on fostering a culture of excellence in the acquisition of essential skills in all educational disciplines through a school-wide core curriculum that orchestrates diversity in learning styles and the needs, interests, and abilities of individual learners. We are founded on the belief that civic leadership is education in action for the good of all people within a global society. Our students will develop the skills they need to make informed decisions as independent critical thinkers who understand their democratic rights as private individuals and their civic responsibilities as public participants in a network of social and political communities. Ultimately, with family partnerships deeply embedded in our foundation, our students will become disciplined, courageous leaders who are inspired to make a difference in America's civic purpose.

We believe that students will give their personal best when they are encouraged to meet high expectations. We also work hard to ensure that families are an important part of our learning community, as they are the ones responsible for supporting us as their child strives for excellence. Establishing strong and consistent routines around a safe environment is the backbone of our school community. Children and adults need a strong sense that they are safe and respected in order for them to perform at their best. We encourage and enforce those procedures so that everyone can strive for excellence.

overview: Mott Hall Community School combines a rigorous program in science, technology, engineering, and math with an ambitious, arts-based grounding in humanities. Our goal is to facilitate growth in the next generation of leaders through the extension and promotion of engineering and arts. We raise the performance levels of students through a collaborative, community-based approach, the endeavors of a committed faculty, and active, engaged parents. Housed in the heart of Throgs Neck, we prepare students for entry into high school by exposing them to the multitude of educational opportunities that our city has to offer. A fully functional science lab, a computer lab, and internet-ready classrooms with interactive technology promote technologically proficient, well-rounded students who are prepared for the challenges of the 21st century.

Our scholars complete a challenging curriculum and work hard to develop their critical thinking, problem-solving, and questioning skills. Our young men give back to their communities through service opportunities. We prepare our young men for life after middle and high school. We believe that young men are best developed when being supported through uniting the work of dedicated educators, supportive families, and actively engaged mentors. We are focused and committed to the school's guiding principles of Academic Excellence, Mentoring, Leadership, Integrity, Character Development, and Community Service.

overview: We are an academic environment that empowers students to develop their strengths. Our school includes families as integral members of our community. Our motto is: "The Future of Harlem, One Student at a Time." We build our school's success on five pillars of promise. First and foremost is an amazingly dedicated staff of educators and support personnel. Second is the implementation of professional development to keep improving our teaching methodologies. Third is a careful selection of resources matching the needs of our students. Fourth is a dedication to collaborations, partnerships, and grants to enrich our community of learners. Fifth is an understanding of the importance of including technological training, resources, and utilization to create citizens ready for the job market of today and tomorrow. P.S./M.S. 161 has won both the Intel Schools of Distinction Award and the National School Change Award (AASA/Fordham University Graduate School of Education/Pearson Education). In Fall 2016 we began a three-year grant with Apple ConnectED through which all students receive an Apple iPad for their learning. We are an NYCDOE showcase school for Dual Language learning.

printedschoolname: Urban Assembly Academy for Future Leaders
overview: Our mission at Urban Assembly Academy for Future Leaders (AFL) is to welcome learners who have broad intellectual interests. We encourage our scholars to develop their wide spectrum of knowledge. Rather than limiting students' adolescent curiosity by having them specialize in one academic area, AFL supports our scholars' intense desire to know and understand. At AFL, we foster an environment that promotes adolescent development and demands academic excellence. Though we are a very small school, we offer our students an abundance of professional opportunities and experiences. Our students travel and get real-life experience to support what they are learning in class. Students at AFL can take advantage of our top-ranked athletic program; science, technology and arts-based elective courses; and advisory program. We challenge, support, and expose our students to the ways in which highly successful people think, so that throughout their three years at AFL they may hone their skills and leave our doors ready to lead the world.

printedschoolname: Knowledge and Power Preparatory Academy IV
overview: In partnership with our parents and the community, we provide a comprehensive educational program to support student academic success, career awareness, and knowledge of self. We accept our students as they are and welcome the challenge of moving them forward to exceed rigorous standards in all classes while empowering them to create goals based on data and personal experiences. Our parents support our uniform policy, extended day programs, Saturday programs, college visits, and other extracurricular activities, and also enjoy the sense of fellowship and strong communication that exists within the school community. We are dedicated to providing high-quality instruction in a nurturing, educationally-diverse, and rich learning venue that promotes civic and cultural responsibility, pride, and high academic achievement. Our commitment to providing a dynamic and demanding learning experience prepares our students for the challenges of living in a competitive and rapidly changing world.

printedschoolname: Columbia Secondary School for Math, Science and Engineering
overview: Students like our family atmosphere and the creative vibe of our teachers and courses. Students also like the opportunities to take courses at Columbia University in high school. Parents like the availability of the teachers and the cultural events that celebrate the diverse community, like our yearly musical, Black History Month celebration, and Hispanic Month celebration. Parents also appreciate the quality of the teachers and the breadth and depth of the curriculum. Columbia Secondary School for Math, Science, and Engineering has one of the only middle to high school engineering sequences in the state as well as a seven-year philosophy curriculum. We created our own community garden in partnership with the New York City Department of Parks & Recreation, which has become an integral part of our community. Our school focuses on hands-on, inventive learning experiences, and our teachers develop field experiences that bring coursework into an authentic setting without losing rigor.

overview: We are a collaborative school community dedicated to improving our students' academic performance while fostering their physical, mental, social, and emotional growth. We provide a nurturing environment, and to address the needs of each student we offer data-driven instruction that support college and career readiness. Through continued collaboration with parents, administrators, staff, and community-based organizations, we prepare every student to meet the needs of an ever-changing society. We envision that each student values education, holds high personal and educational expectations, is accountable for his or her learning, communicates effectively, excels in all areas, connects school and real-life situations, and develops into a lifelong learner. To maintain an environment that is safe and conducive to learning, we implement the Positive Behavioral Intervention and Supports (PBIS) and The Leader in Me programs. By developing well-rounded students, we help them unleash their individual worth and potential to lead their own lives.

overview: New Design Middle School (NDMS) is a small academic community with a focus on design. NDMS uses the concept of design to help meet the academic, intellectual, social, emotional, and artistic needs of our children. Our school integrates the idea, concept, and process of design into a progressive, academic, and high school-ready curriculum, thereby offering an innovative education in a nurturing environment. The school community believes that the design process allows students to participate in a more experiential form of inquiry-based education that is focused on understanding real-world contexts, self-expression, and problem solving.

printedschoolname: Thurgood Marshall Academy for Learning and Social Change
overview: Thurgood Marshall Academy for Learning and Social Change (TMA) offers a small middle school learning program that allows students to work through adolescence in a nurturing environment. TMA is a Middle School Quality Initiative (MSQI) and Showcase school. Staff and students focus on the whole student, including academics and development. TMA provides ongoing communication between parents and school staff. TMA's electronic grading system, Skedula, lets parents identify student assignments and track performance. Our students visit college campuses and see themselves as college-bound. The Parent-Teacher Association provides guest speakers and important information around student education. TMA's strict uniform policy and expanded day program help build strong students. TMA has a School-Based Health Clinic that includes a physician's assistant, social worker, and dental clinic. TMA hosts an on-site Capital One Bank Student-Run Branch. Students can open savings accounts with just one dollar. In The Shubert Foundation/Music Theatre International (MTI) Broadway Junior Program, students get a chance to showcase their talent and perform on Broadway. Incoming middle school students must attend a five-week Summer Enrichment Program.

printedschoolname: The Academy for Independent Learning and Leadership (P.S./M.S. 129)
overview: M.S. 129 functions like a family unit. Students and teachers respect one another. We are proud to be members of the M.S. 129 campus! Our programs are exciting and allow students to take on the challenges of the Common Core. Some of our programs include: Fountas and Pinnell Guided Reading, Rosetta Stone and Achieve 3000 technology program for our English as a New Language students, READY test preparation, Code X, CMP3 math, and GoMath. Parents are grateful for the principal's open-door policy and the structured disciplinary environment that includes a uniform policy and our high academic expectations. Our goal is to promote independent learning and leadership to all of our students. It is essential that our children understand the value of education. It is our job at M.S. 129 to teach our students to value themselves and to help them realize their full potential. They must push themselves to achieve high marks and to be self-directed leaders if they are to succeed in the future.

overview: Since our doors opened in 1969, generations of students, including some of our current teachers, have grown and developed in our classrooms. As we serve pre-k to eighth grade, a majority of our students stay in the school for over nine years. We offer a wide curriculum alongside an extensive Sports Program and an Arts Program that includes Encores!, a program at New York City Center which has affiliations with various museums in New York City (including The Mount Vernon Hotel Museum & Garden) as well as out of state (Plimoth Plantation in Massachusetts). Additionally, we have a strong partnership with the New York Botanical Garden and with the NY Common Pantry Healthy Eating Program. The Healthy Eating Program provides nutritional lessons for students in all grades as well as a parent workshop that involves our school community vegetable. We are a bilingual school committed to providing high-quality education to all students by meeting their emotional, social, and educational needs. We are also proud of our association with the Children's Aid Society, which enhances our services by providing after-school and holiday programs, and other community building activities.

overview: The Multicultural Magnet School P.S./M.S. 212 is a laboratory for learning. This pre-k through grade eight school provides a rigorous, academically rich environment that is fully aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards. The P.S./M.S. 212 learning continuum includes a diverse menu of academic offerings in addition to traditional ones. Some of these courses include NYSESLAT Test preparation, Academic Intervention Services, and technology. Our new STEM lab is sure to promote 21st-century skills that will enable our students to compete at the high school level and beyond. Students at P.S./M.S. 212 are highly rewarded for demonstrating Preparation, Respect, Integrity, Discipline, and Excellence (PRIDE). Our students are invited on trips to museums, NBA games at Madison Square Garden, Broadway plays, amusement parks, and other cultural institutions as a part of our PBIS program. These incentives demonstrate our commitment to educate and support the whole child. We also partner with the CHAMPs program to offer yearlong before- and after-school sports activities. Our ultimate goal is to cultivate lifelong learners who will find their passion and pursue it with diligence.

overview: At P.S. 214, we help students succeed by offering a challenging curriculum based on student interests and a distinctive school culture based on high expectations. Students' character development is fostered through a solid advisory program, a peer mediation program, an active student action committee, and rich service learning opportunities. Through the Skedula online program and quarterly progress reports, we strive to keep parents up-to-date with students' progress. P.S. 214 was one of the proud winners of a Campaign for Middle School Success improvement grant. Eighth graders have the opportunity to enjoy a full day filled with entertainment at the Great Adventures Amusement Park as part of senior activities. We received the distinction as one of the top five most improved mathematics schools in the Bronx by the Daily News (June 3, 2009), and were recognized by the NYC Department of Education as a model school for creating a pipeline and training site for NYC teacher apprentices.

overview: The Bronx Latin School is a college preparatory school for students in grades 6-12. We offer a rigorous program of arts and sciences and encourage serious scholarship, independent thought, and clarity of expression. We work to inspire students to achieve their personal best through collaboration, inclusion, and goal-setting in a supportive environment of high expectations. We believe every child has the right to an exemplary education. We strive to empower our students to thrive in and graduate from college and positively impact their communities. Along with the integration of technology in the classroom, our integrated curriculum engages students and connects rigorous learning in the classroom with the real world. Parents value Bronx Latin's small classes and student support services. These services include daily advisory, before- and after-school tutoring, as well as Saturday test preparation classes. Bronx Latin students all participate in Socratic seminars and exit projects. Bronx Latin also offers accelerated eighth-grade courses where qualifying students will sit for the Common Core Algebra Regents and the Living Environment or Earth Science Regents Exam at the end of their eighth-grade year.

overview: The Professional Performing Arts School (PPAS) partners with top rated New York City arts organizations to provide high quality training in the performing arts and a competitive academic program. In partnership with the theater company Waterwell, middle school students receive 90 minutes daily of acting, dance, and voice classes. Our curriculum provides students with the artistic and personal skills to be leaders in the field and in whatever profession they choose to pursue. PPAS middle school students are guaranteed a placement in one of the PPAS high school arts programs if they choose to stay. We provide a middle school experience that is well-rounded and considers every child's interests, learning styles, and needs. Open auditions will be held for any interested candidate. Audition information can be found at the school website: ppasnyc.org.

overview: Our mission is for our students to graduate knowing how to work effectively, think critically, and act compassionately. With the emphasis on Common Core Standards, students are able to justify mathematical arguments, design experiments, study historical artifacts, and analyze literature. Laptops and SMART Board technology are used to enhance learning. We are a small school with advisories of 15, and our staff works to meet the needs of every child. Town halls celebrate school-wide events, and we provide mediations to resolve conflicts peacefully and with compassion. We provide an environment that focuses on supportive services and developing our youth into leaders. We have partnered with other organizations to provide these additional opportunities for our school community. Children's Aid Society provides daily after-school programs. Students have access to individual therapy through Astor Services for Children and Families located within the school building. In collaboration with Partnership with Children, we offer student leadership and youth development groups such as: Peer Mediators, Student Ambassadors, and Lunch Leaders. Free eye examinations and glasses are available from the Helen Keller Foundation for all students.

printedschoolname: Knowledge and Power Preparatory Academy III
overview: Knowledge and Power Preparatory Academy III (KAPPA III) creates and sustains a college-going culture to ensure all students have the knowledge of a post-secondary education. Students participate in an elective course, College & Career Readiness, to cultivate a culture of high expectations. Students attend college trips and participate in Career Day. Each morning students begin their day reciting a chant. The chants provide a sense of pride and teach students to be responsible, internalize values, and help them develop capacity for self-motivation and self-discipline. KAPPA III uses EMT Machine and ECard system as a school-wide Positive Behavior Intervention & Support system to establish a climate in which appropriate behavior is the norm. Students earn points throughout the week and redeem the points at the KAPPA III store for prizes. Students participate in Multicultural Day, which provides an opportunity for them to learn about different cultures. Every Friday students receive advisory lessons to establish and maintain a climate of positivity and acceptance towards themselves and others. Students participate in team-building activities to enhance problem-solving skills, develop trust, and improve teamwork.

overview: At ACCION Academy, we have a unique opportunity to provide an individualized, warm, and caring environment for our students because our school is just the right size. Serving an average of only 135 students per year, ACCION is less than one-third the size of the average middle school in New York. This means that our compassionate veteran teachers can form meaningful relationships with students and parents on the journey towards success. We can give each child our full attention to ensure they receive whatever services, programs, or activities they need to grow. ACCION stands for "Achievement, Community, Consciousness, Integrity, Opportunity Now!" Our family-oriented school community fosters the highest levels of achievement, mentoring, and service. The student government helps to influence our school's decisions. The CBO we work with is the PHIPPS program. They provide enrichment and recreational activities to promote student autonomy and hands on activity to through role play and problem solving during the after-school program. Furthermore, there are variety of activities including a robotics team, comic book illustration intramural sports, drama, dance, and much more.

printedschoolname: Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation
overview: As a sixth through twelfth grade school, our mission at the Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation is to engage students in a challenging curriculum centered on wildlife conservation and cultivating life skills so that every graduate is ready for success in college, is exposed to the wonders of the natural world, and is prepared to be an independent adult who acts respectfully with regard to his or her community. Our students make significant academic gains and develop a clear sense of personal purpose to affect positive change. Parents appreciate our partnerships with the Bronx Zoo and Phipps Community Development Corporation, which enable us to engage children in a challenging curriculum that has science as part of our core subjects. The Bronx Zoo serves as our extended classroom, and its scientists, educators, and other staff serve as mentors and educators for our students. High school-aged students have internships and seasonal employment at the Bronx Zoo.

overview: Emolior Academy is a small academic community located in the West Farms neighborhood of the Bronx. Our main focus is rigorous instruction that will prepare our scholars for not only their high school experience but well beyond into their college years. We believe in a parent-school partnership and encourage our parents to take an active role in their child's academic experience. We are a uniform school and offer advanced courses in Integrated Algebra and Living Environment. Through our partnership with The South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation (SoBro) we offer an after-school and Summer camp program. Scholars participate in an advisory program and in yearly college visits. Our parent-teacher conferences are scholar-led and parental participation is expected. Through the use of the Emolior Academy school app, parents are able to access scholar progress and communicate with teachers directly to determine appropriate interventions when needed.

overview: Madiba Prep Middle School of Law, Social Justice, and Innovation is a District 16 Gifted and Talented Program school serving scholars in grades 6-8. We are a learning community where scholars are steeped in the rigorous pursuit of critical thinking skills, communication and technological literacy, self-awareness, and social and character development. Parents and community stakeholders support the development of scholars who are productive, contributing citizens in the local and global contexts. Our learning projects will position scholars to take the information that they have learned and propose a solution to a real-world problem within their local community and make connections to our global community. Our students have access to Theater, Art, Jazz, Tap, Hip-Hop, Digital Music Production, Fencing, Golf, Archery, and a range of clubs and teams, and national travel opportunities. From video game and APP design to boat making, Botany and Space Camp we offer activities that nurture and stimulate scholars. We offer a warm and caring environment with a variety of learning opportunities that include double period English, Math, and Science classes. After-School provides an eclectic mix of activities and academic support.

From academics and sports to learning how to cook and exploring career options, our school provides it all. We are a multicultural haven that embraces diversity and promotes respect for all. Our school program builds a strong foundation in preparing students for life, college, and career. A number of school committees and affiliates support our students. Our school is safe, nurturing, personalized, and embraces core values of commitment, honesty, hard work, respect, collaboration, and excellence for all. Parkside Prep provides a private education in a public setting.

overview: P.S. 138 truly believes that all students can learn if they are taught properly. With this motto in mind, P.S. 138's students are constantly being exposed to a variety of academic subjects. Our instructional strategies challenge and benefit all of our pupils. We offer an accelerated program designed to promote students’ intellectual capacity in all subject areas. Accelerated students are instructed two to three grades above level. They are also involved in positive social activities after school, at school, and in the community. P.S. 138 works collaboratively with local colleges in order to promote student learning by preparing students academically and socially. P.S. 138 works with community organizations before, during, and after school to provide students with many opportunities to excel in their respective subjects. Parents, teachers, and the entire community work collaboratively for the benefit of all of our pupils.

overview: Ebbets Field Middle School is an international education center, founded in 2005. Ninety percent of our students are immigrants or children of immigrants. We are proud of this heritage and diversity. Our instructional week is five hours longer than similar schools ensuring all students meet and exceed the challenges of the Common Core and city-wide instructional shifts. We are one of four Turnaround Arts schools in NYC. Turnaround is a presidential initiative for academic success through the arts. Marc Anthony is our celebrity partner and is committed to our school’s success. All of our curricula, from mathematics to social studies, are infused with the arts. To ensure that our students are college and career ready, every student is given an iPad to experience the curriculum through an interactive, hands-on, minds-on format. We have partnerships that extend learning and guarantee the educational, physical, social, and emotional development of each of our students and families.

overview: As a college- and career-bound school, we have high expectations for all scholars, accompanied by high levels of support. As an Extended Learning Time (ELT) school, our curriculum emphasizes Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) in settings where scholars are challenged to use critical thinking skills, connecting their learning to the real world. In order to allow all of our eighth-grade scholars to sit the Living Environment Regent, they take the eighth-grade NYS Science Test in seventh grade. Scholars in our Integrated Learning Academy K354A are also on pace to graduate with Integrated Algebra and US History Regents. We offer art, theater, music, and dance as classroom subjects. A vast majority of our scholars get accepted to their first choice high school, with a number of them attending specialized high schools each year. All classrooms have SMART Boards, along with state-of-the-art technology and science labs, a mobile science lab, and laptop carts. Our scholars set personal goals regarding their learning, with academic intervention services offered to provide the necessary support to meet the Common Core Learning Standards. Parents are kept informed via auto-dials, email, and text updates, a monthly newsletter, and our school website.

printedschoolname: Academy for College Preparation and Career Exploration: A College Board School
overview: The Academy for College Preparation and Career Exploration promotes academic excellence and guides students along a path to self-discovery that leads them to the successful completion of high school and college. Our personalized education plan begins in sixth grade with an emphasis on mastery of English language arts, mathematics, career exploration, and college readiness. Our rigorous curriculum links academics to real-life situations through customized internships, mentor programs, and community service programs. A respectful and welcoming school environment is a hallmark of our school. The active participation of parents and guardians is a critical component of our students' success. Special school features include small classes in all grades (75 students per grade), a multi-layered advisory program, academic and peer tutoring, a college and career guidance center, and career exploration, as well as cultural and sporting activities and competitions.

printedschoolname: Science, Technology and Research Early College School at Erasmus
overview: Science, Technology, and Research (STAR) Early College School at Erasmus is a small screened sixth- through twelfth-grade Early College school. Students entering our middle school are placed into one of four houses where they will compete with their peers—academically and athletically—throughout their educational journey, and become part of all aspects of our school community. Our dynamic team of teachers and Brooklyn College professors are eager to prepare students interested in science, mathematics, and technology for college and the working world. With our partners, we offer a range of challenging academic courses that give students firsthand exposure to the demands of high school and college by using field-based and hands-on methods of instruction. Students will use the rich resources on the Brooklyn College and other City University of New York (CUNY) campuses as their learning laboratories. In addition to their high school diploma, our high school students may earn up to 61 college credits, tuition free, from Brooklyn College enabling many of them to begin college as a sophomore or junior at a CUNY, SUNY, or private university.

The House System: Upon entry into STAR all students are entered into a house. Throughout the year, houses compete in both academic and extracurricular activities. Each house is awarded points according to how well they compete. At the end of the year the members of the winning house are awarded a grand trophy as well as an end-of-the-year prize.

Student creativity, character development, and social responsibility are encouraged and nurtured through individualized guidance, athletics, clubs, fine and performing arts events, and mentorships.

overview: Our scholars are the center of our school. They are supported through a personalized education where we know all of their interests and needs. From online learning, field trips, and solving real-world problems, scholars believe that what they are learning in school is relevant to the real world. They are empowered to be leaders within the school community by taking responsibility in shaping their middle school experience. Scholars voice their interests through their programming of the arts, after-school programs, and advisory. Our parents are part of the school community through an open-door policy which welcomes them to visit our school. Through the Advisory Program, they have a primary point of contact who knows their child’s academic, social, and emotional progress. Additionally, they are kept well-informed on a weekly basis of their child’s progress. We use technology to engage scholars in a challenging curriculum where scholars solve real-world problems in science and social studies.

overview: Nathaniel Hawthorne Middle School provides a nurturing environment where students from grades six through eight are empowered to explore their passions, through facilitated learning opportunities that lead to student achievement. We acknowledge that, as individuals, we all have different needs and aspirations. We collaborate with our families to ensure that a complete education is provided in order to prepare our students for high school, college, and beyond. As a "Respect for All" school, this mission is built into the fabric of our school culture and climate. We are proud to partner with the NYCDOE Urban Advantage Science Initiative, Office of Arts and Special Projects through Arts Achieve, St. Francis College, and the Jose Limon Dance Company to provide rigorous field experiences and differentiated learning opportunities that help to intellectually challenge our students. We believe that Together Everyone Achieves More, which is what makes this school a shining jewel within the community.

overview: We provide challenging instruction in a nurturing environment. Our teachers address the Common Core Learning Standards (CCLS) by infusing technology into our curriculum so that students achieve their potential and are ready to enter college. We have a state-of-the-art computer lab and each class has access to SMART Boards and iPads. Students have opportunities to showcase their literary and artistic talents. We use SchoolMessenger, email, and an online grading system to keep parents informed of their child's progress. We offer after-school programs daily through our partnership with the Samuel Field Y Beacon Program. Through our partnerships, students are provided experiences and enrichment to develop their learning. Our Technology and Fine Arts Department receives many grants. Per an average compiled by the Wall Street Journal, M.S. 158 sends more students to Specialized High Schools than any other middle school in Queens.

overview: Irwin Altman M.S. 172 combines cutting-edge technology, a dedicated and experienced staff, and a student-oriented philosophy to achieve our goal of academic excellence for all of our students. We are acutely aware of our students' unique social and emotional needs as they transition from their elementary schools into the more challenging rigors of preparing for college and career readiness in the sixth, seventh, and eighth grades. We believe that students learn best by authentic and rigorous intellectual engagement aligned to the Common Core Learning Standards. Emphasis is placed on in-depth academic exploration that results in high quality discussion and writing that demonstrates deep and elaborate thinking in all content areas. Additionally, M.S. 172 was noted in the NYCDOE Annual Arts Report for our dedication to Arts Education including visual, and performance arts. At M.S. 172, we provide parents with ongoing contact and school information through our school website, MS172.org and Skedula/PupilPath, emails, and phone messages. In collaboration with our PTA, we promote parent engagement through informational, and both child and parent-centered activities that fulfill our mission of being the educational center of our community.

overview: All children can exceed standards by being part of a nurturing environment that challenges them to reach their full potential. At P.S./I.S. 178, we promote an environment that encourages open communication, and where every community member is a participant in contributing to the school's success. We create a haven where students are empowered and recognized for their unique abilities. At our school, there is a strong commitment to teamwork and collaboration. Staff members, parents, guardians, and students find the family environment which they are a part of to be remarkable. Differentiated instruction and acceleration take place from pre-kindergarten through eighth grade classes daily. After school, there is a plethora of programs to choose from. We are proponents of enrichment and arts programs, as well as sports. We believe that every student is an expert at something and it is our shared responsibility as educators to identify what that is and to tap into that knowledge to develop other skills.

overview: We have a diverse community and a student-centered environment promoting mutual respect for all and maximizing students' potential for high school readiness. Chosen as one of only 11 Chancellor's Learning Partners Plus Schools, we received praise for being in the top 1% of NYC middle schools for student progress in 2015 and again in 2017. We received "Well-Developed" in all 10 categories on the 2015 Quality Review. Teachers address the Common Core Learning Standards in all subject areas and produce exceptional lessons through thematic interdisciplinary learning/teaching. Ryan has three academies (Law & Justice, Media Arts, and Scientific Exploration) that offer the same rich Common Core curriculum with opportunities for additional learning based on academy theme. Each academy offers Honors/SP courses, talent courses, and classrooms infusing technology. Incoming sixth graders all take robotics and art talent courses. We are one of only two schools in NYC offering a full year of Robotics instruction for every sixth grader. We are a Software Engineering Program school offering computer programming/coding. Our school also benefits from a partnership with St. John's University. We believe in helping great children become great students.

overview: Simon Baruch Middle School is a traditional middle school committed to developing students who think critically and who are civic minded. The school utilizes a house structure as an organizational model that allows teachers to know our students well. An assistant principal and guidance counselor are assigned to every grade level to ensure that support services are available to all students. We offer all students the chance to engage in a rigorous academic curriculum that challenges students to think critically and independently. Students engage in a balance of independent learning tasks and collaborative learning experiences. Our rigorous core content is supplemented by extensive arts and technology offerings that provide students with opportunities to develop their interests and talents. Our school supplements the regular instructional program with an extensive after-school program that provides students with academic enrichment, academic intervention, arts, and athletics.

overview: East Side Middle is an academically successful, nurturing community. Our teachers help our students better understand the world in which they live so they can act upon that knowledge to make that world a better place. Our students learn to think as professional writers and read as literary critics and editors; they learn to study the past as historians and the natural world as scientists. Teachers and staff know students individually and address their specific needs in all grades. In their advisory classes, sixth graders are prepared for their middle school experience in such areas as time management, emotional literacy, and organizational skills. Parents appreciate our staff's in-depth knowledge of individual students, as well as the personalized attention students receive. Families appreciate the accessibility of the administration and instructional staff and the sense of community that defines the school culture. We are fortunate to have an involved and responsive parent community.

overview: While at P.S. 126/MAT, students will engage in a creative and rigorous curriculum that is geared toward fostering collaboration, inquiry, research, public speaking, and overall social-emotional development. Students will interact and incorporate technology in all of the core classes, with opportunities to learn coding, animation, and robotics. In eighth grade, all of our students will be offered the course work necessary to take the Earth Science and Algebra I Regents exams as well as the Spanish Proficiency exam. Our elective program allows students to major in fine arts, percussion, or band, providing students the necessary skills and preparation for high school auditions. Additionally, we have an extensive competitive sports program that offers 23 different sports for both male and female students.

overview: M.S. 131 is a vibrant school community where all students are valued as individuals with many talents and expertises. Students are challenged in many ways. Throughout their middle school journey, students are encouraged to develop their voices in academics and through participation in school events and activities. Students are well supported by the teachers and administration in all areas. We use research-based best practices to ensure that all students achieve their best. Parents feel welcomed by a school that responds to their concerns and needs. We also offer a unique three-year arts program where students major in one of three areas: Visual Art, Dance, and Instrumental Music. We offer Mandarin Chinese as a foreign language, and our dual language program (English/Mandarin) will expand in all three grade levels in 2017-18 school year. Students enrolling in this dual language program will develop their language proficiency in both of these languages by the end of eighth grade.

Parents appreciate the diverse student population and dedicated staff, and they also value the accessibility of the administrators and teachers. Students and families work closely with their grade level assistant principal and guidance counselor. In addition to a strong core curriculum, Wagner has one of the largest music programs in the city, providing approximately 500 students with instrumental courses. overview: M.S. 177 prepares students to be critical thinkers, effective problem solvers, and powerful communicators in a rapidly changing 21st century world. By embracing academic rigor, student voice, collaboration, self-direction, and empathy, our students will have the confidence, tenacity, and skills for success. We pride ourselves on our small, tight-knit community in which every adult knows every child. To do this, we utilize our small school size to provide students with individualized and small-group instruction. Our advisory periods allow for daily check-ins and the promotion of our core values that help our students build strong bonds and respectful relationships with their peers. To enhance students' love for learning, we offer enrichment classes and team sports in addition to courses such as STEM and Spanish. This approach allows students to continue exploring the different topics that might interest them and continuously grow throughout their middle school career.

overview: At 217, we pride ourselves on being a "big city school with a small-town feel." Our small class sizes allow the teachers to get to know students on a deeply personal level. In addition, subject area teachers follow the same group of students through sixth, seventh, and eighth grades, which provides the students with the opportunity to interact with teachers academically and socially throughout middle school. Our families appreciate the support they receive during their child's transition from elementary school to middle school. We offer a wide array of opportunities for students to explore their non-academic interests during the school day. We also provide academic enrichment throughout the year. We have a modern building that is open, clean, and bright. Our hallways are lined with flags representing the countries of our many international students and families. Our state-of-the-art facilities offer updated computer labs, and ActiveBoards in every classroom.

overview: The Ella Baker School is a pre-K-8 public school located on the Upper East Side of Manhattan in the Julia Richman Education Complex. We are a non-catchment area school and accept students from all five boroughs. We serve a population of approximately 320 students from culturally diverse backgrounds. A critical aspect of Ella Baker’s mission is to provide continuity in each child’s school experience from kindergarten through eighth grade. It is our expectation that our students will continue with us through the eighth grade. We do not hold middle school tours, as it is rare that there are spots open in the upper grades.

printedschoolname: The Clinton School for Writers & Artists (M.S. 260)
overview: The Clinton School for Writers & Artists is close-knit and collaborative community. Students who succeed thrive in a small, academically rigorous school. We are in our own new construction building off of Union Square, at 10 East 15th Street. This facility has an 8,500 square foot gym, an outdoor roof play space, a modern library, science labs, and studios for music and art. The middle school has its own separate space on the upper floors, with separate start and dismissal times, but we are one school with one administration. The upper grades program culminates in the International Baccalaureate Diploma Program. Students who are admitted into our middle school have the option of staying with us for the full seven years. The middle school has a comprehensive, free after-school program through our partnership with Manhattan Youth.

overview: Students appreciate our teachers' energy and enthusiasm for the subjects they teach, as well as their accessibility—teachers are always happy to provide additional support in academics or to help students work through problems. Parents appreciate the values we place on building traditional academic and critical-thinking skills. Our curriculum integrates learning about a range of issues and provides students with a structured forum for taking action to make the world a better place for all. All eighth graders take Algebra 1. Students at P.S./I.S. 276 have the opportunity to build leadership through participation in sports teams, student government, and community service. Students can graduate with distinction in Academics, Service, Arts, and Athletics. Through all this work, parents recognize that we pay close attention to each student's academic, social, and emotional well-being.

overview: M.S. 297 is a middle school located in Greenwich Village. We are a school committed to celebrating diversity and engaging students in a rigorous, inquiry-based academic program that challenges and supports all students. The course work is designed to reflect the inclusive philosophy of the school, to inspire lifelong learning, and to develop students as citizens in the 21st century. The academic curriculum will be supplemented with rich and extensive art and technology offerings to develop students' interests and talents. Partnering with local cultural and community institutions will help us enrich our curriculum. Students will be immersed in electives designed with their interests in mind, a variety of art experiences, and a comprehensive sports program. Advisory, community service, and collaboration will be essential components of the students' leadership experiences. M.S. 297 is a school that believes that all students can achieve their goals in a supportive and trusting environment that values curiosity, creativity, and initiative. As of September 2018, this school will be located at 75 Morton Street.

printedschoolname: NYC Lab Middle School for Collaborative Studies
overview: Located in Chelsea, our community embodies our core values of collaboration, compassion, academic rigor, and diversity and pluralism. Our Labbies put the "lab" in collaborative! Our academically nurturing and rigorous environment fosters curiosity and lifelong learning. Students engage in inquiry across all disciplines. In humanities classes, we combine social studies and ELA and offer enrichment courses on unique topics. To enhance our core curriculum, we provide Regents math and science courses for students ready for the challenge. Students also participate in national competitions (math, writing, and vocabulary) and work with local arts organizations. We are proud of our inclusion program and offer supports so all students succeed: full- and part-time ICT classes, small group specialized instruction, executive functioning support, and all related services. Across the three years, all students take typing, transitions to middle school, coding, advisory, visual art, and drama. Our PA works tirelessly to supplement students' experiences and organize family events such as a Lunar New Year celebration. Former Labbies report back that teachers' high expectations and three years of Spanish have prepared them well for high school.

printedschoolname: P.S. 347–"47" The American Sign Language and English Lower School
overview: The mission of P.S. 347 is to provide a joyful learning environment that celebrates the education, growth, and uniqueness of every student. An engaging and rigorous standards-based curriculum is offered in American Sign Language (ASL) and Standard English, and is supported in small classes that provide children the opportunity to achieve their personal best. Our staff is committed to inspiring and encouraging curiosity, empathy, and social awareness by developing higher-level thinking skills and exploring real world issues that extend into the community. By fostering a partnership with families, we support individual student goals to enable each child to become an independent and responsible lifelong learner, and prepare them for success in the journey to higher education. All Signs Point to Success!

overview: As a pre-K-8 school, Spruce students can expect many opportunities to build on the successes of elementary school, with an adolescent spin. As a growing school, students and families have a unique opportunity to help shape their education in collaboration with a team of dedicated, talented educators. Our instructional approach emphasizes inquiry and depth. All students engage in daily humanities blocks where they read, write, inquire, debate, and research. Mathematics plays a large role in our curriculum, and happens daily. Our math instruction emphasizes both conceptual understanding and fact fluency. All students engage in science instruction across the week, utilizing our state-of-the-art science lab. Our curriculum also emphasizes social and emotional development through advisory. We offer visual art and music. Students also engage in electives which range from coding to sculpture to dance. At Spruce Street, we expect students to serve as leaders across our school.

overview: The Institute for Collaborative Education (ICE) is a small, community-focused school where the needs and academic interests of our students come first. Teachers utilize a project-based curriculum that emphasizes student-centered inquiry, forming substantive arguments, written and oral presentations, and the active and ongoing exchange of ideas. At ICE, we encourage students to develop their own points of view and practice the intellectual disciplines of conducting formal research and defending complex academic arguments.

overview: School of the Future students like our dynamic, creative teachers and interesting classes. Students also like that we know each of them very well and each of them is challenged academically. People who visit often express how alive our school feels! We are proactive about the intellectual, social, and moral growth of our community and see ourselves as people who are helping to raise smart and thoughtful teenagers. Parents appreciate that their children are pushed both in terms of their academics and their personal responsibility. They appreciate our small class size and strong sense of community. Parents like that we work with them towards their child's success. We follow the principles of the Coalition of Essential Schools, including personalized learning and teaching students to use their minds well. Our high school students design four year-long research projects and present their work to a committee of staff and students, and our middle school students begin to prepare for this experience in the sixth grade.

overview: Quest to Learn students are curious, inventive, playful, and empathetic. Students, families, our community partner Institute of Play, and faculty work together to build a robust, rigorous, and responsive school community. Quest to Learn classes are interdisciplinary and they follow a design and project-based learning approach. In their core classes, students take on different roles such as professional publishers, spies for King George III, conflict resolution specialists, or amusement park architects, as they apply new skills and content. Students also enjoy opportunities to pursue interests in design and technology, including game design and digital photography. Students participate in a small group advisory, which provides an opportunity for academic goal-setting, college-readiness activities, and community building. Twice each year, Quest students engage in our Boss Level Challenges, a design-challenge interim where they work in teams to tackle real world problems.
