overview: At Life Sciences Secondary School, we provide an innovative academic curriculum that facilitates the development of critical-thinking skills through project-based learning across all subject areas with a specific focus on the sciences. All middle school students receive extra support in math and ELA during the school day to ensure they are prepared for high school. We offer after-school programming five days per week until 5:30pm through a partnership with Hands In 4 Youth. This program includes academic support as well as athletics, dance, art, computer programming, mock trial, and many other elective options. Students also have the opportunity to attend a sleep-away camp multiple times each year through this partnership. We nurture a safe environment where students know that they are capable of growing and improving. Our commitment is to prepare every student for high school, college, careers, and beyond.

overview: At Lower Manhattan Community (LMC), we work to build a rich middle school experience for all of our students by combining rigorous curriculum, an intense focus on the arts, two years of foreign language, and a strong advisory and community service experience for all students. Our students participate in an enormous range of arts and after-school programs which run Monday-Friday until 5:45pm. Our students take many field trips into the community, to conduct community service, build upon our academic curriculum, and explore our city. Students also attend overnight trips during their middle school experience. LMC is located in the 26 Broadway Building on the sixth and seventh floors. In this historic building, the NYCDOE constructed brand new facilities in 2010. Classrooms are stocked with SMART Boards, laptop computers, iPads, and other technologies.

overview: City Knoll Middle School believes that young people have the ability to become whatever they want with the right education, guidance, and support. Our community understands the interconnected world that we live in, and strives to create learning experiences for students through an approach that is in tune with their interests and strengths. We also believe that students learn best when they are provided with real world opportunities to learn through the arts and projects that are relevant to their lives. The arts, public speaking, and presentation are core features of the instructional approach and support the development of critical thinking and creativity. City Knoll has established partnerships with the Museum of Modern Art, NYC Outward Bound, Middle School Quality Initiative, Learning Partners Program, ExpandEd Extra Book Clubs, Manhattan Youth after-school program, Morgan Library Book Arts Project, and Urban Advantage. Students appreciate teachers immersing them in rigorous project-based curricula, while nurturing them to be empathetic, independent individuals capable of shaping their own futures.

Our children are challenged to work to their fullest potential each day, while enjoying the safe, family environment of our K-8 school. The parent foundation of P.S. 19 gives us the stability we need to provide our students with an all-around sense of unity. Our strong administrators offer direct support to ensure that every day is more productive than the last.

overview: Our vision at P.S./M.S. 89 is that students learn best through building relationships, ensuring academic rigor, and engaging in culturally relevant and responsive learning that will develop the social and emotional aspect of individuals. We follow the Big Picture Learning model that believes in personalized education for all students. In addition, we believe that creating and providing innovative, personalized learning environments that work in tandem with the real world of their greater community will best serve our children. All students have access to technology during the school day and at our After-School and Saturday Academy. Our curriculum provides students with interventions that aid in setting high expectations and creates classrooms where students can apply knowledge, set and achieve positive goals, feel and show empathy for others when questions and discussions are taking place. We believe that establishing and maintaining positive relationships creates a nurturing school community.

overview: Michelangelo Middle School is where students begin their quest for excellence. Our students learn how to become critical thinkers, problem solvers, decision makers, and caring, ethical citizens. In addition, our students are prepared for high school and college by our special emphasis on the Common Core Learning Standards. Michelangelo has an active Parent Association that works with our parent coordinator to communicate with parents about various events, including student celebrations, school plays/concerts, Honor Roll breakfasts, Honor Society Night, and Family Nights. In addition, parents and students can view upcoming assignments on teacher web pages as well as monitor their child's progress via PupilPath. Parents are guided in the high school application process by our guidance counselors. Our graduates have been accepted into many of NYC's specialized high schools.

overview: We are dedicated to providing students with an engaging and rigorous learning experience to which they have a voice in creating. We are committed to collaborating to determine the specific academic and cultural needs of our students and to designing innovative ways to challenge students at all levels. Through this work, we are preparing students for the 21st century and holding them accountable for ownership of their academic success. At our school, we value the importance of literacy as a pathway to success in all areas of life. As a result, we integrate strategic-reading periods (reading clubs) into our weekly program. Three times per week, students participate in reading clubs that are tailored to their individual reading levels and needs. We believe in the importance of personal ownership and accountability along with the development of social capital during the middle school years. At our school, all students engage in advisory coursework which provides students with opportunities to discuss difficult social scenarios as well as learn how to maneuver through them successfully. Through our student government students develop their decision-making skills while positively impacting the school community.

overview: At Bronx Green, our primary goal is to effectively collaborate and prepare every student with the skills and knowledge to become exceptional learners and leaders. Further, we provide an environment conducive to learning in which every student can advance academically, socially, and emotionally. Families enjoy numerous opportunities to participate in their children's educational accomplishments through end-of-unit celebrations, parent workshops, Honor Roll breakfast ceremonies, Broadway shows, local MLB and NBA games, and end-of-the-year Museum Night. We offer all incoming sixth graders the opportunity to attend our Summer Summit program. The goal of the program is to acclimate students and families to the middle school experience and unique opportunities at Bronx Green. All students have access to technology based instruction via the use of Chromebooks, iPads, iPad Minis, two fully equipped computer labs, and SMART Boards. Through our College Access for All affiliation, our students enjoy the college experience by visiting colleges/universities located in- and out-of-state.

overview: We believe education is the great equalizer and that knowledge brings about opportunity, voice, and joy. Teachers have the ability to mold and influence the lives of each child to be a successful member of our society. We believe that, given the right opportunities and guidance, all children can strive toward excellence! Students like our school because we have a hands-on, task-based learning environment that encourages collaboration and discussion. Students enjoy learning in our classrooms that have a studio feel with areas for station work, independent study, and conferring. In our school, students are full participants in their own learning under the guidance of teachers and staff. Our parents appreciate the level of support that their children receive through our programs. Parents recognize our commitment to preparing each student for high school, college, and beyond.

overview: School Motto: "If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together!"—African Proverb. We are a college preparatory, community school with a strong academic program and diverse enrichment activities suited for college-minded scholars. Our values-driven academic and advisory programs emphasize persistence, accountability, communication, and teamwork—qualities we know are important for academic and personal success. Because of our college-prep focus, all scholars must manage a heavy workload and attend our Expanded Learning Time program, making for a longer school day. In all, we provide learning and enrichment activities for scholars that, for some, begin as early as 7:45am and end at 9pm. We also provide weekend programming as well. Our doors are always open! We are also excited about our dynamic Advisory program that ensures a personal and academic mentor for every scholar. Advisors work with scholars and families to not only ensure academic success but social and emotional success as well. Bronx Alliance is a hard-working school, committed to providing every scholar an amazing middle school experience. At Bronx Alliance, we are family—we love each other, we love our work, and we are going far together!

overview: The community of leaders at Leaders of Tomorrow is dedicated to personal and academic excellence. Choosing to live in the community obligates each member to a code of civilized behavior. Allegiance to these ideals requires each of our students to refrain from and discourage behaviors which threaten the freedom and respect every individual deserves. Each student at our school is considered a leader and as such we expect them to adhere to the following creed: "A Leader practices personal and academic integrity. A Leader respects the rights and property of others. A Leader will discourage bigotry, while striving to learn from differences in people, ideas, and opinions. A Leader will demonstrate concern for others, their feelings, and their needs for conditions that support their work and development."

overview: Our school provides a holistic learning environment dedicated to developing 21st Century skills. Our curriculum focuses on intellectual, social, and emotional development, as well as left-, right-, and whole-brain activities. We encourage students to work collaboratively, think critically, solve problems, analyze and synthesize information, practice adaptability, be curious, and build communication skills. Our teachers use Socratic seminars, performance tasks, project-based learning, technology, and traditional methods of teaching. Teachers check for understanding multiple times during instruction, as well as at the end of a lesson. There are weekly and bi-weekly assessments, and evaluations given every six to eight weeks under state testing conditions. Projects and performance tasks allow students to transfer their skills into a product. Academic intervention services are provided in core subjects. The level of rigor allows our students to have success in high school, college, and beyond.

overview: At Pelham Academy students learn to work hard, support each other, and celebrate their success. Through regular and consistent work with their teachers and advisors, students are taught how to analyze situations and recognize what is in their best interest. Students begin to explore their interests in the sixth grade, and continue that journey through eighth grade. Throughout their time here they will have the opportunity to participate in high school and college visits, to create art portfolios, and prepare for the Specialized High Schools Admissions Test. Our collective goal is to help mold our children into reflective young men and women who are prepared to be competitive in high school, college, and beyond. Our students are provided with the environment and support they need in order to learn, develop, and mature. Our learning community consists of everyone and anyone who can impact the lives and futures of our children.

overview: Cypress Hills Community School (CHCS) is a small, community-based, dual-language school where students learn in Spanish and English. The school's mission is for all students to become fully bilingual and bi-cultural, and to be deeply concerned about themselves and each other, their community, and the world. We offer native language instruction to all students, including: Spanish language arts, content area instruction in Spanish, and targeted tutoring groups during the school day and after school. The small environment allows students to develop positive relationships with their teachers, where they benefit from both academic and emotional support. CHCS has developed a philosophy guided by Project CARE (Communication, Accountability, Respect, and Effort). These core values provide a common language we believe is necessary for fostering and maintaining a peaceful and productive environment.

overview: Students have the opportunity to use local field sites such as the New York Botanical Gardens, the Bronx River, and NYC parks to hone their observational, research, and data collection skills. Our partnership with the Albert Einstein College of Medicine allows students to work closely with medical staff in researching the history, causes, and impact of specific health issues within the community. Parents appreciate our strong Parent/School Connections, which provide opportunities to collaborate with teachers, students, and partners to enhance student learning. Our “Learn and Serve” philosophy encourages our students to become responsible citizens, able to solve problems and help their surrounding community. Students are offered an education that includes a solid foundation in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and that provides role models through close association with our Parent Learning Partners and community-based organization partners.

printedschoolname: One World Middle School At Edenwald
overview: One World is a small school committed to understanding who our ambassadors are in order to teach them. We support our ambassadors in developing as lifelong learners by working with them to develop their character, intellect, wellness, and a desire for lifelong learning. Ambassador and class accomplishments are recognized and celebrated! Some of our most successful clubs have been founded by our ambassadors—our Tech Team produces videos for school assemblies to showcase school highlights. Other opportunities include attending multi-day trips to various universities and historical sites. Similar to the United Nations charter, all cultures are celebrated at One World Middle School—real issues are discussed and we provide an ongoing platform for dialogue. Leaders, activists, and ambassadors have a common thread in that they communicate clearly and appropriately for the audience and message. For these reasons, the areas of writing, speaking, and listening are carefully nurtured. We weave real-world applications into our academic curriculum to connect classroom lessons to real-world issues, problems, and situations. Our high expectations are balanced by support and accountability to ensure ambassadors reach their fullest potential.

overview: Students enjoy our classroom projects where they take on the role of experts in many different career fields and attempt to solve the problems that challenge our community, country, and world. Students also enjoy our advisory groups where they work with a small group of other students and an adviser to discuss important personal issues, explore NYC, and develop our school's core values. Students love our enrichment and extracurricular activities. Parents like our online grade book that allows for instant access to teachers, grades, and student behavior reports. Parents enjoy our many project celebrations where students present their projects and receive awards for their hard work. Parents also like our Brain Pump programs that allow for students to get extra help, make up work, and even expand their learning. The five core values at Bronx Park are: professionalism, reflection, innovation, determination, and empathy.

overview: Welcome to I.S. 171, Home of the Lincoln Scholar. We at Abraham Lincoln Intermediate School 171 are a community of educators dedicated to the belief that every child can learn and is entitled to a high-quality education. Our students have the opportunity to take the Algebra and US History Regents courses as well the Spanish Language Proficiency exam. We were the first in the city to host the Middle School Student Success Center (MSSSC), which focuses on supporting students' high school and college choice and preparation. Students can choose from visual arts, debate, theater arts, Spanish, coding, and physical education electives. We offer the following after-school programs: Theater/Drama, Video Game Truck, Modeling & Etiquette, and Debate Team. Students can also participate in Student Government, Project BOOST, STEM Club, Student Dances, College Prep assemblies, and MSSSC year-long activities. We also host Family Honor Roll dinners, Student of the Month assemblies, family movie nights, staff vs. student basketball games, and our annual Community Carnival.

overview: James P. Sinnott has a magnet program focused on health and health professions. There is also a wellness committee which focuses on a month-by-month health theme that is ingrained in the culture of the school. We offer students an Honors program with Regents courses, Spanish Dual Language Cohort, and a Dance Cohort. We also have the only Day NYPD/FDNY Explorer Program with the Learning for Life advisory curriculum. All students are exposed to restorative circles in advisory. As participants in New York City's iTeach/iLearn program, students receive a laptop computer for daily use in each class and all classrooms are outfitted with SMART Boards. Parents are always invited to our school to help build culture and to celebrate our students. We provide our students with a stable, secure, and structured learning environment and the highest quality classroom instruction. A wide variety of support and intervention services are also offered. We strive to achieve academic excellence.

overview: The mission of J.H.S. 292 is to create a secure environment that embraces each student's individual talents and maximizes his or her potential. Our programs assist in preparing students for higher education while developing their sense of responsibility and building self-esteem. In our quest to produce successful young adults, we have created an open-door policy where teachers, parents, and students work side by side on academics and life experiences to further the growth of students. This is done by the implementation and sustenance of mentoring groups and Student Council, all of which focus on fostering leadership potential, community service, and helping students gain the world view that they need. Parents are impressed by the fact that we offer a performing arts component where each child has the opportunity to participate in an elective that will complement their academics, making them well-rounded citizens.

overview: Our FALCONS enjoy the personalized attention that they receive in our small, nurturing learning academies. Our small academies afford us the opportunity to provide a nurturing environment, where students are able to create lasting relationships with the staff. We strive to cultivate a dynamic environment of advanced thinkers, high achievers, and model citizens. The staff works to develop an educational program based on the unique needs of each student. In collaboration with parents, we support the intellectual, emotional, and social growth of students. We strive for academic excellence by maintaining high expectations. We believe that every child can and will succeed academically and will be able to develop a strong personal sense of discipline and social responsibility. Gateway FALCONS are provided with a rich academic curriculum which is enhanced through the use of SMART Boards and mobile computer labs and differentiated based on student need. Our open-door policy ensures that parents will have full access to their child and parents are able to continuously check their child's progress through the use of our computer grading system. Gateway FALCONS have been accepted into TEAK, Prep for Prep, and A Better Chance programs.

overview: The Teachers College Community School (TCCS) is a university assisted, non-selective Pre K-8 demonstration school that applies stateof-the-art knowledge and best practices in teaching, learning, and child development. It opened in 2011 and is growing by one grade each year. TCCS is admitting its first sixth grade class in 2017. The mission of TCCS is to provide a child-centered environment that will inspire and challenge all of our students to become independent thinkers, problem solvers and life long learners, and to work as a collaborative unit of parents, faculty and staff to ensure that our students perform their optimal best. We are a nurturing community that believes students learn best through positive framing, setting personalized goals and knowing what they need to do to achieve their goals. TCCS takes pride in a rigorous curriculum that develops students’ knowledge, concepts and skills, and encourages proactive and engaged learning. The school community is notable for its diverse and respectful learning environment and attention to nourishing the whole student. TCCS has a relationship with Teachers College which provides expertise and services to help ensure student success. For example, TCCS provides rigorous and individualized English Language Arts instruction through the Teachers College Reading Writing Project (TCRWP). Other special features of the school include: customized CCS aligned Math curriculum and customized Science curriculum both designed with support from Teachers College, small group targeted interventions and accelerated enrichment, school garden, STEAM programming in partnership with Salvadori Center and Youth Force, and instrumental, vocal and music composition courses in partnership with Teachers College and Manhattan School of Music.

overview: Academy for Young Writers is a supportive, sixth through twelfth grade community school focused on college & career readiness. In 2012, we relocated to a new building, equipped with state-of-the-art technology. We use an individualized approach to help every child succeed academically & personally. In addition to rigorous core classes, students take courses in musical theater, dance, computer science, technology, band, and foreign language. Every year, writing courses craft original works of writing that are published in grade-wide collections. Students also have the opportunity to attend field trips, overnight nature trips, and college trips. We offer a variety of after-school activities. We practice a restorative justice model, teaching students how to talk about and deescalate conflicts. We build community in small advisory groups to allow students and staff to develop relationships and the advisor is the point-of-contact for parents—the first staff member students reach out to when they need support. Parents can view their student's grades online. We have an active Parent Teacher Association (PTA). Parents appreciate the ease to which they can communicate with teachers, advisors, and administration about students' progress.

overview: Our focus on academic success and curricular programming is paramount. We are a small school and offer classes of approximately 25 students which allows our students to develop academically and socially. Our teaching staff is extremely caring and focused, and students have multiple opportunities to work through their academic challenges with effective guidance and support. Our staff is very accessible and professional. We are particularly encouraging and open to families, as evident in the number of siblings who attend both the middle and high school sections. We have a full-size pool, state-of-the-art computer room, and a new media center.

overview: At Spring Creek Community School (SCCS), a grade six through twelve school opened in 2012, students engage in project-based curriculum that emphasizes critical thinking, questioning, and problem-solving. Arts and technology are integrated into daily instruction, and students are programmed for additional math and literacy periods to support their success across the curriculum. Students benefit from enrichment electives and school-based partnerships with arts and academic organizations. All classrooms are equipped with SMART Boards, document cameras, and multiple computers. Students are in an advisory that provides each child with social, emotional, and academic supports. Advisors support students throughout middle school, and build long-term relationships with families. Parents appreciate our focus on collaboration and communication, and all parents are registered with an online account, which gives them access to student progress reports and allows them to contact teachers directly. In order to support our six through twelve model, students who attend SCCS in middle school are strongly encouraged to continue their education in our high school.

overview: Frederick Douglass Academy VIII (FDA VIII) is a college preparatory middle school. Students of Frederick Douglass Academy VIII enjoy the variety of the instructional program that our school offers. Additionally, students are required to participate in community service activities as part of their graduation requirements. Students also have the opportunity to attend international trips and overnight college tour trips. Parents appreciate that our students are required to participate in community service activities as part of their graduation requirements. We have high expectations for our students and hold them accountable for their actions. Parents also like our small learning environment and the family orientation. All students are known by name and treated with the utmost care and respect. Our students have many opportunities to participate in community service programs to become global leaders and thinkers of the 21st century.

overview: Van Siclen Community Middle School is a safe space for students to strengthen their academic and social abilities through rigorous instruction in the core curriculum while teaching them how to work collaboratively. In our dynamic classrooms, students generate solutions to address real-world issues, utilizing technology infused throughout the program to facilitate development of their 21st Century skills. Students participate in individualized mentorships with school personnel to foster interpersonal skills and develop college- and career-readiness. Dedicated educators and mentors, who are devoted to each child's academic and emotional growth, support students in every subject area and encourage integration across subject areas. Subjects are taught thematically, focusing on issues that are currently facing our society.

overview: At Vista Academy, students enjoy the safe learning environment and great conversation about their learning with classmates and adults. The Decision Making Period (DMP) is at the heart of Vista Academy's character education curriculum. Students appreciate the real-life scenarios encountered in this course and find the information relevant to their lives both in and out of school. Students feel supported by the adults in the community and are comfortable having personal and academic conversations about their lives and future in both English and Spanish. Vista Academy is a small community school that provides strong academic instruction while placing a direct emphasis on values like respect, responsibility, and perseverance. Parents appreciate the school's focus on high academic achievement while developing their child's social and emotional character through the DMP. Parents value the nurturing environment that supports students academically and socially.

overview: Our students enjoy that their classes are organized into small communities. Students can choose from a variety of after-school activities to spark their interest and make them excited to come to school. Students like that their teachers find out about students' interests and use them to plan their lessons. For example, teachers might use sports to help teach math and forensics in science. Parents appreciate our school's focus on college and career success. With our small class sizes, and readily available teachers, we give individual attention to our students in order to build their character and academic ability. Parents like our commitment to keeping them informed about their child's progress through our online grading system. We integrate technology into school life as much as possible in order to enhance our instruction.

Classes involve small group and individual assignments, as well as interactive projects. Advisory, electives, and one-on-one coaching gives students the chance to develop their own learning plans and try new activities. Parents love the one-on-one attention that each student receives in his/her academic coaching sessions. Parents also love that we develop independent and resilient thinkers who are prepared for the demands of high school and beyond. We partner with our sister school, The School of the Future in Manhattan.

printedschoolname: The East New York Middle School of Excellence
overview: Our scholars enjoy the individual attention they receive at East New York Middle School of Excellence (ENYMSE). At ENYMSE, our motto is "Success Without Excuses," and our scholars are held to that expectation every day. Scholars are able to pursue their education in a nurturing environment. Our school just completed construction of a state-of-the-art science lab. Scholars experience STEM units in both math and science courses. We enrich these programs through strategic partnerships and trips for our scholars. All of our scholars are involved in an array of clubs and teams allowing them to explore pursuits outside of their academic interest. Our after-school program enriches their experience through academics, sports, and the arts. Parents like the small school experience where each student has a STAR coach (advisor). We are committed to a strong parent-school partnership. We invite you to join our school community and find out why ENYMSE is Brooklyn's best-kept secret.

overview: The mission of Highland Park Community School (HPCS) is to cultivate empowered leaders and bold thinkers that create innovative solutions to problems locally and globally. Each grade has a real-world, project-based theme through which all instruction is connected. Students like these projects because they provide opportunities to tackle important social issues, make a difference in their community, be creative, and have fun while they apply new skills. Our scholars benefit from rigorous, exploratory instruction that prepares them for the best high schools and provides the foundation needed for college and career. Our advisory program supports students' social and emotional needs, and guides them as they develop and act on Individual Goal Plans (IGPs) focused on academic and personal goals. We encourage parent involvement that goes beyond attending PTA meetings-family members are encouraged to join us on field trips, volunteer, participate in projects, and support our initiatives.

overview: Our school provides a well-planned transition program to help parents and students acclimate to the new requirements of middle school. Students at Shell Bank enjoy getting to know their teachers in small group settings. Our grade structure allows teachers, administrators, and guidance counselors to get to know students on an individual basis. Individual support is given to students and parents during their transitions through middle school. Shell Bank maintains unique programs that focus on college- and career-readiness, as well as an ongoing collaborative support system with parents. Students enjoy a selection of courses that incorporate project-based learning and student interest. Our school also has a partnership with North Shore Animal League in a unique program called Mutt-I-grees where students work with therapy and shelter dogs. Our staff focuses on character development and civic responsibility, offering experiences that are intellectually and physically challenging. Our school also has the only Specialized Program for the Intellectually Disabled in District 22, which is staffed by teachers with special training and experience in this area.

printedschoolname: Intermediate School 78: The School of Architectural Design & Innovative Technology
overview: At I.S. 78, The School for Architectural Design and Innovative Technology, our mission is to provide all students with engaging, rigorous, and technology-based learning opportunities which align with the Common Core Learning Standards. All classrooms are air-conditioned and feature a 65-inch LED flat panel SMART Board. Our students enjoy personalized attention from our dedicated grade teams. Every student has access to a full-time academic counselor, a vibrant and diverse arts program, and meaningful after-school activities. Teachers utilize online academic enrichment programs (Achieve3000 & Waggle Math), to collect data that informs instruction, which leads to improved ELA and math skills. Through our Schoolwide Enrichment Model (SEM), students develop skills, foster positive relationships, and experience social growth. Our enrichment clusters, as well as our embedded organizational skills program, promote creativity and collaboration, in support of college- and career- readiness and community service. In partnership with staff, families, and the community, we foster the emotional, social, and intellectual growth of our students, in order to prepare them to reach their full academic potential and become outstanding citizens.

overview: The M.S. 379 community will work collaboratively, as partners, to engage students in rigorous learning opportunities preparing them for high school and beyond. Our expectations are that students will grow global competency and develop academic skills and knowledge necessary to address shared global challenges as they become productive members of our local community and global society. We aim to develop inquiring, knowledgeable and caring young adults. The knowledge and skills students gain in our school will empower them to become active, compassionate lifelong learners. Our students explore content through challenging project based and self-directed learning models and make connections to our local and global communities. M.S. 379 is opening in a new building for the first time in Fall of 2018. The building name chosen by the community is the College Point Collaborative School of Leadership and Innovation. Those themes will be reflected in the culture of the new school. Student activities and electives will be decided with input from the community and the interests of the entering sixth grade class.

overview: Our students receive a quality education in a small nurturing learning environment. It's a place where everybody knows your name. Parents appreciate our small educational community, our emphasis on science and technology, and our desire to equip each and every student with the necessary tools to become a leader of tomorrow. We are part of the iLearnNYC program. iLearnNYC schools are implementing online and blended learning to expand current school boundaries that limit how and when a student can learn. iLearnNYC empowers teachers, administrators, students, and parents with cutting-edge resources, including online content, real-time data on student work, and many more educational tools.

overview: P.S./I.S. 206 is a multi-cultural school with approximately 1,500 students, 360 of which are in our middle school. Students have the opportunity for engaging discussions centered on critical thinking. Staff and administrators know students by their names and support their individual needs. Parents often want their child to attend our school because they feel confident that their child is in a safe and highly rigorous school. Students enjoy a healthy balance of strong academic instruction along with opportunities to develop their strengths in technology and the arts. Community service is a staple of our school and students enjoy the rewards of helping others. One of the most coveted positions is that of a student mentor where middle school students are able to support elementary students both academically and socially. SMART Boards, digital projectors, iPads, personal Androids, and over 200 new wireless laptops ensure that our students are ready for the technology-driven future.

overview: Cunningham is a family-oriented, safe, and nurturing school whose students come from more than 30 different countries. In an effort to prepare our student body for college and career, we empower them to think critically and engage in rich peer-to-peer collaboration across all disciplines. Cunningham focuses on science, engineering, technology, math, sustainability, and environmental issues through hands-on STEM related activities, robotics, coding, Ever-fi, residencies, field trips, partnerships, and service-learning opportunities. Students will become communicators and collaborators while learning new and exciting engineering and technology skills, conducting research, applying math concepts, and striving to create a model for a sustainable community. The program heightens students' curiosity in STEM subjects by laying a solid foundation for futures in science, engineering, math, and tech fields through all subject areas by teaching the critical skills that life and work demand.

overview: Andries Hudde, I.S. 240 STEM Magnet School, promotes choice, equity, diversity, and excellence for all students. Students have full access to cutting edge, state of the art technology, preparing them for 21st century STEM based careers. Our students make real world connections through instruction. We create, collaborate, character build, and foster good self-esteem. We educate the whole child. We believe our instruction builds community, perks student curiosity, and bridges gaps. Our mission is to empower our students by providing solid academic skills, supporting them with resources that will make for dynamic future leaders and entrepreneurs. Our goal is to maximize student growth by providing them with a well-rounded, interdisciplinary education through project-based learning. Students will experience hands-on innovation, making for critical and creative thinkers. Students love to be at Hudde because of the many after-school and Saturday activities. We are rigorous, safe, and nurturing. We value the uniqueness of each student, preparing them for academic, artistic, musical, physical, and social/emotional growth. Hudde is more than a school, we are a family that is "Magnificent in Midwood".

overview: Marine Park J.H.S., located within the beautiful surroundings of Marine Park, provides a nurturing school environment where students develop college- and career-readiness through high level academics, various arts programs, and technology. Tech is infused into all of our classrooms through the use of SMART Boards, laptops, iPads, and e-readers. Students research skills on building and design which they explore through our award-winning STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) programs. Students also discover their talents through our arts programs. Marine Park embraces the comfort of our students in a fully air-conditioned building including all classrooms, the gymnasium, the cafeteria, and the auditorium. Parents and teachers enjoy a close relationship. There are multiple opportunities for correspondence including emails, PupilPath, School Messenger, phone calls, SLT, PA meetings, and parent workshops.

overview: I.S. 381 offers an intimate and nurturing environment for students, as well as one in which academic rigor and excellence is valued. Our staff works collaboratively to develop enriched, rigorous, and individualized curricula designed to meet the learning and social developmental needs of students. I.S. 381 offers both accelerated and schoolwide enrichment courses that promote students' interests and abilities. Through the use of iZone technology the school offers high school curricula in Algebra and Living Environment Regents. The school also offers Specialized High Schools Test preparation. Additionally, every child has the opportunity to participate in Latin as a foreign language, visual arts, and schoolwide enrichment clusters. The Schoolwide Enrichment Model is a research-based model designed to provide students with opportunities to engage in a wide range of experiences that will enhance creativity and passion. Enrichment clusters include: photography, drama, movie making, visual art, LEGO robotics, dance, designing games/coding, track and field, and blogging. The school also has a partnership with a community-based organization, Sports and Arts in School Foundations, that offers an after-school program.

overview: We believe that a well-rounded individual, passionate about learning and committed to his or her talents, is best prepared for the demands of the modern career landscape. Through the approach of the Schoolwide Enrichment Model, the staff of M.S. 890 is committed to creating an engaging, supportive, and rigorous learning environment for everyone. Students choose an enrichment cohort and work side-by-side with their peers to dive deeply into their selected content area. Through guest speakers, field trips, and authentic learning tasks, students become experts in their selected field and work towards a culminating capstone project in senior year, during which they solve a self-identified problem or question and present their findings to the community. As a result, students grow as independent thinkers and apply what they learn to devise solutions that have a positive impact on their world. In addition, we offer opportunities for students to pursue their interests in sports, music, drama, clubs, foreign language, and writing—both during and after school. Parents have a voice in school-based decisions via the School Leadership Team, Parent Association, fundraising, and our varied parent engagement events.

printedschoolname: The Robert F. Wagner Jr. School (P.S./I.S. 78)
overview: We focus on providing our students with a challenging and global education while meeting the emotional, creative, and social needs of all students. We focus on critical thinking and problem solving through interactive literacy and math activities, enhanced through an integration of the arts into the core curriculum. Parents are actively involved in their children's education and we share the joys of watching our children grow, learn new skills, and make friends. We implement the Renzulli Schoolwide Enrichment Model (SEM) in all grades and include parent talent, community volunteers, and experts from the community in developing an enrichment curriculum. By addressing the needs of all students, including our students with special needs, English Language Learners, and gifted students, the SEM Model engages all of the children in visual, musical, spatial, and kinesthetic activities through their interests and talents thereby enabling them to enhance their academic potential.

overview: Community School 111Q has achieved success on the path to demonstrable improvement. A forerunner in Renewal efforts, we are implementing cutting edge educational programs that are supporting our scholars, parents, teachers, staff members, and the community. Our scholars engage in discussions with their peers and staff as they study academic and social theories and writing in all of the core subjects. We have implemented the Teacher's College Writing Curriculum, evaluative portfolios in core subject areas, the use of daily formative assessments to monitor progress, independent reading, myON, and Mathletics computer-based interventions and a balanced approach to literacy, science, social studies, and math instruction.

overview: Our Academy for the Intellectually Gifted at P.S. 122 is a district-wide Gifted and Talented program with a rich history. Our program design aims to maximize the degree of academic acceleration while providing a diverse array of enrichment opportunities and an emphasis on the physical, social, and emotional well-being of the exceptional students who are admitted to our school. We are committed to the goal of creating lifelong learners by providing a stimulating academic environment centered on students' interests. Academic content work incorporates many opportunities to engage in problem-based learning (PBL), challenging and creative projects, and teacher assessments, as well as self or peer assessments. Students are well prepared for academic requirements of New York City's specialized high schools. At "The Academy," we welcome the constructive participation of all stakeholders. We recognize that vibrant home/school/community partnerships increase the chances of maximizing our students' potential.

printedschoolname: Albert Shanker School for Visual and Performing Arts (I.S. 126)
overview: I.S. 126 is committed to providing a safe learning environment where all students are held accountable to reach high levels of academic achievement. We challenge our students with a rigorous curriculum and college-readiness expectations. In addition to Regents classes, we offer preparatory classes for the Specialized High School Admissions Test (SHSAT) and the NYS State exams. I.S. 126 has a partnership with City Year, who assist our students in developing their academic and leadership skills. We enrich our students through arts residencies with our partners. We have a science lab and computer labs that are state-of-the-art. These programs allow us to extend the academic rigor in the classrooms. I.S. 126 believes parents are equal partners in their children's education. We foster an open-door policy, where parents are encouraged to communicate and build successful relationships with school leaders. We offer bus service for eligible sixth graders. We also have arts residencies with Community Word Project and Alvin Ailey.

Our shared vision is to inspire students to pursue their dreams by fostering a safe, trusting, and nurturing environment that will promote academic, social, and emotional growth of all scholars at P.S./I.S. 127Q. Our school offers three different program choices for English Language Learners (ELL). We have a dual language program that starts in kindergarten and continues through middle school. Students entering the dual language program are given a baseline assessment in order for our school to provide the best services to ELLs.

overview: Nestled in the heart of New York City, Steinway Intermediate School serves the multicultural population of Astoria. Our school consists of three academies that provide students with small learning environments, thus fostering a sense of community and closer collaboration between the school and parents. The Jewels Academy houses all sixth-grade students, while the seventh and eighth grade students are equally split between The Albert Einstein Academy and The William Shakespeare Academy. Dedicated to providing rigorous academic instruction, the school offers a strong Honors program, which provides in-depth study and prepares students for Regents exams in Living Environment and Integrated Algebra I, while also promoting the arts and humanities, by offering dance, music, and two art courses. This year 30 students were accepted into NYC's Specialized High Schools. Moreover, 34 additional students were accepted into Townsend Harris, Bard, Frank Sinatra, Beacon, Baccalaureate, Manhattan/Hunter Science High School, High School of Fashion Industries, and Talent Unlimited.

overview: The Louis Armstrong Middle School (LAMS), opened in 1979 with the mission of bringing together a group of culturally diverse children to help them grow academically, emotionally, physically, and socially. At LAMS, students are provided a personalized, caring, and supportive environment. The staff works to build the childrens' confidence and work ethic in order to develop a sense of pride in their choices, actions, and quality of work. In addition to the core subjects, LAMS offers Accelerated Regents courses, foreign language courses, music courses, art courses, physical and adaptive fitness courses, and technology courses. The school is affiliated with Queens College, Vaughn College, National Middle School Association, and National School Reform Policy. Our school is an original recipient of the U.S. President Award for Excellence, has been recognized four consecutive years as a Reward Status School, and by the NASSP as being, "one of the top 100 most effective middle schools in the U.S."

overview: Intermediate School 230, The School for Civics in the Community, provides activities that engage, challenge, and stimulate students. Parents appreciate that we are a nurturing school, and as a result we are a very popular school. Our sixth-grade academy is housed in our annex which is located directly across the street from the main building. The main building houses our seventh and eighth grades. The small learning community of the annex provides a very important transition for students entering middle school. Intermediate School 230Q has developed a positive reputation based upon our challenging academic curricula, supportive teachers, and safe environment. Each year, a very limited number of seats are available for students residing outside of our geographical zone in Jackson Heights.

printedschoolname: The Young Women's Leadership School of Astoria
overview: The Young Women's Leadership Schools (TYWLS) were established to nurture the intellectual curiosity and creativity of young women by supporting the whole girl in order to maximize academic achievement, social emotional well-being, and post-secondary success. TYWLS of Astoria is supported by The Young Women's Leadership Network (YWLN) and its College Bound Initiative in order to replicate the best practices of private and independent girls' schools. The school approaches learning in a dynamic, participatory fashion, encouraging students to take responsibility for their own learning. The school uses technology in nearly every class and every day to create a meaningful, cutting edge 21st century learning environment. Students are provided with rigorous STEM, humanities, and arts opportunities as they prepare for college and becoming future leaders. TYWLS of Astoria is an Apple Distinguished School for Technology.

overview: Students like our enthusiastic teachers who make learning interesting by bringing hands-on activities, field trips, and projects to our units of study. Students collaborate with a diverse group of peers through our supportive and challenging classrooms, advisory program, and school-/PTA-run dances and other celebrations. Our after-school options include a free five-day-a-week program run at our school by 82nd St Academics, as well as other choices including award winning debate and chess clubs, sports and dance teams, and an amazing theater program. Parents value our high standards in all classes including Algebra for All and Science Regents for every eighth grader as well as our intervention and extension groupings for reading, writing, and math. Our online grading program allows families to stay updated every week on their child's academic and character progress. Our new shared building is located along the East River as part of the Hunter's Point South development area and contains a beautiful auditorium, music room, art room, and science labs. We are a fully inclusive school, meeting the needs of both gifted and talented students and students with learning or physical disabilities.

overview: Q300 is one of several NYC citywide gifted and talented schools. We are committed to a high-quality education that strives to cultivate a genuine love for learning in all of our students. Our approach is driven by national standards of gifted education with the full understanding that we are stewards of our students' cognitive and affective growth. As a result of our strong collaboration with parents and external organizations we are able to offer our students: music, LEGO robotics, dance, logic, second language(s), architecture, and chess. Our efforts to shape the whole child scaffold an exposure to rich information and knowledge, critical-thinking skills, and effective and relevant modes of communication.

overview: The mission of the Sojourner Truth School is to prepare you for lifelong learning as responsible, caring, productive citizen in partnership with your family. Administrators, teachers, students and parents will work hand-in-hand to create a supportive atmosphere where all students are pushed to their personal best. During your years at Sojourner Truth School, you will encounter a rigorous, high-level instructional program, which will prepare you for success in the future. Through a wide range of academic course offerings, enrichment programs, guidance support services, and other school experiences, the Sojourner Truth School will provide you with the learning competencies you need to go on to higher education. Together, we will achieve our educational mission to help you fulfill your potential by assisting you in becoming a critical thinker, active problem-solver, inquisitive reader, diligent researcher, and effective writer. We expect you to be a model citizen and strive to achieve your personal best during your time as a student at Sojourner Truth School and beyond. Our community looks forward to opportunity to meet you in the coming months and hope you consider visiting our school as you make your middle school choice.

printedschoolname: P.S./M.S. 165: The Robert E. Simon School for Leadership
overview: At P.S./M.S. 165 all students LEAD. They Lead by example. They Excel. They Achieve. They Do what's right. Our students value our supportive learning community, where we emphasize meeting every child at their level and helping them become leaders of their own success. We have Honors, Dual-Language (Spanish), and ICT classes. Twenty-First century skills are woven into the fabric of instruction: every student has access to a MacBook Air and a Google cloud account hosted on our school's domain. Students learn coding and build machines and interactive robots. Our ELA curriculum is the TC Reading and Writing Project. Our math program focuses on critical thinking and number sense through CMP3 and Number Talks, building toward an eighth grade algebra Regents course. We value the arts and music, through which students learn keyboarding, drawing, painting, and sculpting. We perform two musicals and host talent, fashion, and art shows. We are opening a ceramics program this year. Our advisory curriculum is the Leader in Me, and students learn the 7 Habits of Highly Effective People. We encourage all students to participate in the Boys & Girls Harbor after-school program, which offers digital art, film, dance, sports, and homework help. Learn to LEAD at 165.

overview: Students are empowered to be active participants in their own learning and engage with teachers who guide them to meet and exceed the Common Core Standards. Our social-emotional curriculum and close-knit grade level teams promote an inclusive environment that cultivates acceptance and respect for all students in our diverse community. Students engage in project-based learning experiences that build independence, nurture creativity, and challenge students to think critically and analytically. Families value our student-centered community, personalized learning experiences, arts partnerships, and accelerated ELA and math enrichment programs. Families also love the dedication of our teachers who collaborate to plan meaningful classroom experiences. Parents appreciate the many workshops, special events, student-led conferences, science fairs, and portfolio exhibitions. Students have academic coaches, lead student-led conferences, develop digital portfolios, and participate in advisory.

overview: We believe that all children achieve success when provided with active learning experiences that challenge and build real-life connections. We also believe that the education of every child begins at home and is continued through a partnership between parents, educators, and the community. Our school mission is to provide every student with the foundation that prepares them for success in the college and/or career of their choice. Our school community is committed to the Three Es: Excellence in teaching and learning, Engagement to promote active learning and problem solving, and Enrichment for positive social and emotional development of well-rounded citizens.

overview: At P.S./I.S. 191 students are engaged in rigorous curriculum and tasks that prepare them for high school, college, and their career. We have a strong focus on project-based learning, which we have recently extended into a STEM/STEAM program. To enhance our project-based units of study, our students engage in museum trips and work with both museums and cultural institutions around New York City. Students discover their passions by being exposed to the visual and performing arts and other cultural riches that contribute to the development of the whole child. Additionally, students collaborate with teams of teachers who provide them with academic and personal support. Students engage in programming designed to stimulate, provoke, and develop their imagination. Students' work is exhibited in a museum-like way during our biannual Dream. Think. Do! Gallery Tour. As we move into a brand-new building in September 2017, we look forward to enhancing our rich programming through an expansion of our technology, the arts and sciences, as we continue our quest to foster lifelong learners.

Students utilize technology in all subjects, and engage in self-exploration via curricular, extracurricular, and after-school offerings. Parents appreciate our focus and attention to each student's background, special gifts, and learning style. Computer School students make numerous trips to New York City cultural institutions to magnify their learning experiences. Students leave the Computer School exceptionally well-prepared for high school.

overview: During the 2015-16 school year, Dual Language Middle School was the highest impact public middle school in New York City. We are dedicated to the development of bilingual, bicultural students through a strong academic program in English and Spanish. We believe that developing linguistically and culturally diverse students leads to higher levels of language proficiency, achievement, and self-esteem. What parents like best about our school: our open-door policy, frequent and ongoing communication, online grade book, free after-school program for all students, academic rigor, high expectations for all students, excellent safety record, small class size and extensive student support, Regents coursework (Algebra and Spanish), & comprehensive advisory program. What our students like best: warm, inviting environment where all students feel valued and safe; teachers' extensive knowledge of all students, well-prepared teachers, wide variety of after-school programs, use of technology, camping trips we take every year, the Broadway show they see every year, the NBA Mentoring program, opportunities to attend after-school enrichment or homework help every day, and student-led conferences.

overview: A rising star, M.S. 256 is a small school with approximately 150 students and is home to some of the most dynamic and engaged teachers in New York City. We are a community with a passion for educational excellence. Our school's size enables us to provide a supportive, diverse learning environment which fosters each student's academic, emotional, and athletic growth. Our successful French Dual Language Program, the only one in Manhattan, provides students from French dual-language programs and French native speakers the opportunity to further their study of French language arts and select content area courses in French. Recognizing the many developmental changes that middle school students face, we focus our practices and curriculum on supporting our students to ensure they are ready to tackle the challenges of high school and beyond. We empower our students to become productive citizens and leaders in our school and all facets of their lives.

overview: Community Action School is built on the belief that the entire school community must support the academic, social, and emotional growth of all students. Our collaborative teaching staff ensures that all students receive individualized support for high levels of academic growth. Our curriculum is aligned to the Common Core and both challenges and engages our students. Our students enjoy frequent academic and cultural trips to complement lessons being learned in the classroom. All seventh-grade students participate in a three-day overnight trip to the Clearpool Environmental Education Center in upstate New York to build teamwork and community. Our advisory program focuses around student goal-setting in addition to nurturing the social and emotional growth of our students. Parents value the way that administrators and instructors make themselves available to assist with any concerns. Community Action School is listed as a "notable" school by Inside Schools.

overview: West End Secondary School promotes and supports scholarly endeavors through a rich and varied curriculum. The school emphasizes the core values of creativity, compassion, wonder, and resilience. Through an interdisciplinary approach, utilizing New York City as a learning lab, students experience rigorous coursework through authentic expeditions, which culminate in public presentations of learning. Expeditions engage students in case studies that examine and analyze compelling topics from a variety of perspectives, often working with experts in the field. Established partnerships with local museums provide students with opportunities to be the stewards of the city's future. Multiple partnerships with arts and performance organizations offer students a comprehensive cultural foundation in which their innate sense of wonder will thrive.

overview: Students enjoy a curriculum which stresses critical thinking, problem solving, and independent group research. Classrooms have wireless internet access, SMART Boards, and laptops. Students meet weekly in small groups for advisory with their homeroom teachers to discuss academic and social issues. Manhattan School for Children (MSC) parents and students appreciate our community, supportive teachers, and differentiated instruction. MSC iLearn facilitates communication among the staff, parents, and students. MSC has an open-door policy for parents to drop off/pick up their kids at the classroom door. This helps parents form close ties to our school community. MSC is a part of the Chancellor's iZone 360, engaging students in project-based learning with real world applications. MSC's greenhouse, an environmental science lab and urban farm, supports a science curriculum tying together studies in biology, chemistry, physics, earth sciences, and sustainability.

overview: The Anderson Middle School (AMS) provides a judicious combination of an accelerated and enriched curriculum for the distinct needs of gifted learners. Our upper grades are fully integrated within our highly successful K-8 school. With only two classes per grade, the relationship between students and teachers is personal and supportive. This smaller population fosters a strong sense of community. Guided by educators who recognize the needs of children with outstanding intellectual potential, we provide intimate, differentiated, and departmentalized instruction that encourages critical thinking, creative problem solving, divergent thinking, research, independent study, collaboration, and self-evaluation. Parental involvement and support sustains the spirit and growth of AMS. The Anderson School seeks a diverse student population, including ICT students, and welcomes applications from across the five boroughs. Please visit our website to review our admissions rubric before applying.

printedschoolname: Wadleigh Secondary School For the Performing & Visual Arts
overview: Wadleigh Middle School Scholars have the unique opportunity to receive three years of performing and visual arts instruction as they complete a rigorous Common Core-Aligned curriculum. Our performing arts courses include: instrumental music, vocal music, dance, and theater arts. Middle school students perform alongside our high school students at least three times a year, during our Fall, Winter, and Spring Showcases. Wadleigh is distinctive in that it exposes students to arts professionals via career fairs, in-house cultural events, and trips. Middle school students also participate in Early College Awareness and attend college tours and fairs. Wadleigh also provides advanced elective courses in Regents Algebra and Regents Living Environment. Wadleigh offers sports, peer tutoring, and several after-school programs. Parents appreciate the Wadleigh nurturing environment which allows their children to individually grow and excel academically and artistically.

The caring and dedicated staff at West Prep will continue to encourage all students to set high goals for themselves and to reach for their dreams. At West Prep we empower our scholars to be "TITAN STRONG". Through our community partnerships, our scholars learn about themselves not only academically, but also physically, socially, and emotionally. Our mission is to provide our students with a foundation for success as they matriculate through West Prep, and meet their full potential in life.

overview: The mission of the Special Music School is to teach musically gifted children through highly structured instrumental training and a standards-based academic program. The school prepares students for professional music careers while recognizing that not every student will choose such a career. The underlying philosophy of the Special Music School is the belief that music education for gifted pupils requires: 1) extensive opportunities to work one-to-one with an outstanding instrumental faculty; 2) a structured, sequential music curriculum; 3) opportunities to perform before audiences; and 4) interaction between general academics and musical studies. Our goal is to see each child reach his or her academic and musical potential. Our vision is that all students will become lifelong learners and critical thinkers in our caring and respectful learning environment. We encourage parental involvement in all aspects of the school.

overview: P.S./M.S. 4 is a school where scholars come first. Our vision is to create a culture of self-reflective scholars who use learning opportunities to develop a global awareness of the world. The school society, comprised of parents, guardians, students, teachers, and staff, makes a combined effort to provide an educational experience that teaches the whole child. We acknowledge students' mental, social, emotional, and physical needs. Our mission at P.S./M.S. 4 is to devise and implement a comprehensive educational program that encompasses all members of the community and actively engages them in real world experiences, technological advances, and meaningful discourse. The fundamental components consist of data analysis, goal-setting, teacher teams, reflective practitioners, authentic professional development, parental involvement, and the establishment of societal norms.

overview: Our students enjoy our small environment where they are treated like family. We celebrate our students' talents through science and curriculum fairs, talent showcases, and cultural celebrations. Students like our SMART Boards and computers in each classroom, laptop carts for each grade, and computer lab. Parents embrace our challenging academic experiences and high standards. We offer families tools to support their children, including weekly progress reports and an online gradebook. We work closely with our PTA to offer events that celebrate our community and showcase our students' talents. Our school is proud to have proficiency scores in ELA and math that nearly triple district averages. We were listed as "Among the Best" middle schools by the NY Daily News in 2012. We have been profiled in each edition of New York City's Best Public Middle Schools: A Parent's Guide. Our graduates regularly gain acceptance into highly competitive specialized, private, and parochial high schools.

overview: The Knowledge and Power Preparatory Academy (KAPPA) is modeled after KIPP Charter School, in partnership with Replications, Inc., which was founded by John Elwell. There are currently four KAPPA schools in NYC that have been modeled after our school. KAPPA is unique in that over 90% of KAPPA scholars do not reside in the community. The vast majority of our students commute to school via public transportation. KAPPA is in its 12th year as an autonomous school and 17th year as an educational institution. Our student population is diverse. Students hail from Central America, South America, Africa, Asia, and the Caribbean. The vast majority of our students speak a second language at home, adding to the uniqueness of our school. What these diverse students have in common is that they value education, which is a direct result of strong parental support at home.

printedschoolname: The Rafael Hernandez Dual Language Magnet School (P.S./I.S. 218)
overview: Students at P.S./I.S. 218 spend half of their time learning content information in English and the other half learning in Spanish. Our goal is to have students become biliterate, meaning that they can engage in academic work in both languages. Additionally, our middle school students are given accelerated instruction in mathematics and science in anticipation of taking the Algebra I and Living Environment Regents in the eighth grade. And, through a wide variety of experiences, students view the world through a global perspective. Whether communicating with college students abroad or conducting research for a company like Time Inc., our students use the skills learned in the classroom in authentic ways. Students thrive in an environment that enables them to be productive citizens who respect and embrace linguistic and cultural differences. Parents enjoy a welcoming environment which encourages them to participate in the education of their children. They embrace the high expectations of our teachers, and work alongside us to foster well-rounded young adults. The school also encourages parents' personal growth by providing workshops on current topics.

We deliver a diverse and integrated curriculum that reaches across all disciplines at all grade levels. Students are encouraged to meet academic challenges with openness, critical thinking, and creative problem solving. We promote an atmosphere of cooperation and a can-do spirit with respect for individual differences and community values. We strive to have our parents, teachers, and community members actively involved in making students' middle school experience as fulfilling as possible.

printedschoolname: The Eagle Academy for Young Men
overview: The mission of the Eagle Academy for Young Men is to develop young men committed to the pursuit of academic excellence, strong character, and responsible leadership. We are a college-preparatory school focused and committed to the school's guiding principles of academic excellence, mentoring, leadership, integrity, character development, and community service. We are part of a network of six all-male schools across the New York City area which work in collaboration to support the needs of our community and our young men. Our scholars are provided rigorous academic opportunities, offering Regents courses in the middle school and intensive reading interventions though the Middle School Quality Initiative. We partner with parents to educate the whole child, and provide regular community-based parent workshops open to all families. We prepare our students to join the ranks of future leaders in society. Our scholars are expected to conduct themselves professionally, wear uniforms, and participate in cultural rituals as part of their normal school routines. Successful male professionals from a wide array of careers act as mentors to provide scholarship and internship opportunities.

Every adult at the BWA is here to support the students in their academic and personal growth. Our school day goes from 8:20am-2:40pm with the opportunity to opt in to a variety of after-school activities such as LeAp, Robotics, Book Clubs, Coding, and more! overview: The Urban Science Academy—as our name makes clear—is a science academy. Our students engage in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) through multiple pathways, and enjoy opportunities to engage in hands-on learning. We understand that the jobs of the future will require minds trained in the ways of the sciences. We work with a large number of organizations: Urban Advantage/American Museum of Natural History; the Lego Mindstorm robotics program; Plaza Construction and Salvadori for real life engineering experiences; the NYC Solar Schools Program; Genetics with Cornell University; and NASA's Cubes in Space. All these projects are joined in our 21st Century After-School Program under the umbrella of the Urban Science Maker Space, where students also engage in 3-D printing, coding activities, and select individual paths to learning and creating. In our other classes, students benefit from engaging instruction and exciting extracurricular activities. Class sizes are kept as small as possible, and our school's culture emphasizes student responsibility and healthy development. We have an active Student Council, and a Peer Group Connection program that attaches eighth grade leaders to mentor our sixth graders.

The academic success of our students is a collaborative effort and is the result of our staff's expertise, planning, professionalism, extensive parent involvement, students' commitment to success, and an atmosphere of social equity in our school.

overview: The mission of P.S./I.S. 137 is to create a community of students, parents, and staff joined in the pursuit of excellence through academic achievement and personal growth. We seek to provide a challenging curriculum with flexibility to meet the needs of every student. We want our children to have esteem for themselves and others, and to be knowledgeable and sensitive to their own culture as well as the culture of others. We place a strong emphasis on literacy and personal expression of ideas through speaking and writing. We believe that all students should master basic skills. We stress scientific exploration and application in technology as well as physical and artistic expression. We exhort parents, students, and staff to live and work as a community, focusing on the needs of our children and celebrating their successes.

overview: Students love our small class sizes and the individualized support they receive in every class. Some students have the opportunity to accelerate their progress through middle school and high school classes using our mastery-based course design and a variety of online learning options. Some eighth-grade students have access to ninth-grade courses during the Spring semester. Daily after-school support classes help students understand course expectations, complete assignments, and practice necessary academic skills. Talent development courses in the art, music, and athletics allow students to explore non-academic interests throughout the school day. Regular group advisory sessions, after-school activities, and internships offer the chance for students to develop leadership skills, get to know their peers, explore careers, and have fun.

overview: Our students love learning about the environment and how their decisions can make the world a cleaner, better place. They enjoy working in our garden and greenhouse, growing healthy food for lunch. Students develop the skills that will prepare them for success in high school through hands-on activities and experiments in our new science and technology labs. Students also enjoy expressing themselves through music, art, dance, technology, theater, and other electives. Parents like our school's focus on high school and college preparation. Our Advisory program helps maintain a small, family-oriented community that focuses on students' personal development. Parents love our commitment to the community and the close relationships our school builds between teachers, students, and families. Our school's new LEED Platinum Certified building has state-of-the-art classrooms and labs, a library, a greenhouse, and outdoor roof with a garden.

overview: Our students work on many collaborative and research projects, building the skills needed to analyze or support a position. Our school culture supports not only students’ academic achievement but also their social and emotional growth. We collaborate with parents in our work and maintain an open-door policy that allows all parents to have full access to the principal and staff. Our parents find it amazing that we have a 24-hour turnaround for returning calls and responding to all emails. We integrate technology across all subject areas and we facilitate Socratic Seminars at the end of each unit of study. We were authorized as an International Baccalaureate (IB) school in March 2014 and we are the first standalone New York City public school to receive the IB Middle Years Program (IB MYP) authorization.

overview: I.S. 59 prepares all students to read, write, compute, speak well, and behave in socially acceptable ways in order to become independent members of society. The students participate in enrichment programs such as Project-Based Learning, Regents classes in math and science, Project Arts (performing arts academic connection), and an after-school and Summer program with the YMCA. Many of our parents are active participants in our school community throughout the school day and in Adult-Learning Computer Classes. We use TeacherEase, a web-based communication system to inform our parents of their child's successes. Our students have the highest acceptance rate in the NYC area for the Legal Outreach Program. Selected eighth grade students participate in the school's partnership with Northwell-LIJ for extended science instruction. In September 2013, we implemented a new academy for gifted students, The Rising Star Academy for Scholars, and a new state-of-the-art multi-purpose playground.
